"We parked at the glacier car park (on the other side of the road to the main park centre). The car park gets quite full but we did manage to jag a spot immediately. The walk up from there to the bottom of the glacier is quite steep and takes 10-20 mins at least depending on how you feel. It can also be a bit slippery with loose gravel and rocks. On the way, note the signs that show where the glacier was in the recent past - and some people say there is no climate change? It may be for normal, natural, cyclical reasons but the glacier is definitely receding.I found it interesting to see the scratches on the rock from where the glacier had moved over it.As it is a reasonably hard walk up to the glacier, there are fewer people there than you might have expected from seeing how busy the centre is across the road.It was quite a cold day when we were there and noticeably colder at the glacier than down in the car park so rug up regardless and be prepared."
"I visited the Ice Field in late October, which may not have been so ideal. It was still a wonderful experience, starting with the drive to this area. The actual frozen glaciers are far into the distance, and is not safe to approach due to unstable, snowy paths. But even from afar, the ice looked nice. Knowing I was staring at nature that has stood still in time for millions of years makes this visit worth it."

"Peoples, please forget about taking some glacier ruining bus (unless, of course, you happen to have limited mobility) and take a hike on the Athabasca Glacier, which is the same one those large vehicles take you on. I used a tour company called Ice Walk and we hiked on it for almost six hours and what a GREAT experience. (Please don't hesitate to read my review on them). You get to see millwells (moulins), which are basically waterfalls into caves, of which our great guide Ian took one of our hands so we could lean over and look inside. We also saw crevasses, ice caves, streams and the upper part of the Athabasca glacier. The hiking was fairly easy, with the exception of jumping over a couple of streams. If you're a person that's getting a bit long in the tooth, like myself (almost 49) and are pretty fit, you can do it no problem. We had a 61 year old woman in our group who had no problem with the hike. I find it quite funny when the title of this attraction is Columbia Ice Field, where most of those that have written reviews refer to seeing it by getting off a bus. You only see part of the Athabasca Glacier. The Columbia Icefield is huuuge. It's the largest ice Field in the Rocky Mountains in North America, lying partly in the northwestern tip of Banff National Park and the southern end of Jasper National Park. It's about 325 square kilometers/125 square miles in area, with the depth between 100 meters/330 feet and 365 meters/1,200 feet deep. You can see pretty much the whole Icefield by taking the Parker Ridge Trail and the Wilcox Pass Trail across the street from the glacier. The trail heads start not far from the Icefields Discovery Center. If you're in good shape, you could do both in a day pretty easily. The nice thing about the last two options is they don't cost a penny to hike, just your energy. I plan on doing those two trails next time (planned on doing them this time, but the glacier walk was irresistible to me when I found out about it).  Thanks for reading. If you feel this information helped you, it would be appreciated if you would tap the below. Thank you"
"The Glacier Adventure that leaves from the Icefields Center is a great experience. A short bus ride takes you to an exchange point where you transfer to their Ice Explorer vehicles. These huge machines transport you over a glacial moraine and out onto a glacier, allowing you time to get out and walk on a glacier. Its cold, so take a warm cover-up. And it is slippery. But you do get a good idea about glacier make-up and how they shape the earth."

"We drove up to the base, parked, skipped the visitor center and the lines, and walked up to the toe of the glacier. If you take the bus it drives up by a more circuitous route and deposits you in the middle of the glacier. We found the walk easy. The ground was a bit uneven but it was not a problem to get very close to the toe where we could see up the entire glacier. As any geologist can tell you, the underside of a glacier is a messy place with piles of glacial till forming a terminal moraine. It was possible to see the gouges the glacier made in the base rock. Overall a nice walking side trip while travelling in the ice field parkway."

"The Columbia Ice Field (about 125 sq mile in area) is located between two National Parks Jasper and Banff in Canada. It is the largest Ice Field in the Rocky Mountains. Our process of exploration was full of pleasant surprises. It started when we got on board the huge vehicle known as ‘Ice-explorer’ with custom built huge tires (each costing USD 4000)! The vehicle was being driven by an extremely efficient and charming young lady named Sandra. We drove in the mountains and moved around glacier ice pads on the snow coach. We were taken inside the ice fields and we got down from the coach on Athabasca glacier. Subsequently we travelled around other parts of the Columbia Ice field. Our driver cum guide Sandra showed us the unique features of the Ice Field. We saw the multiple layers of the Ice Blocks, the fossilised tree trunks in the Ice Field, the blue tinges in glaciers and the formation of the lakes where glaciers are melting down over time."

"We drove from Lake Louise to the Brewster Icefield Discovery Center building south of Jasper. That was an hour and a half. Parking was tricky. We bought our tickets in advance, but we still had an hour wait to get on the icefield bus. So we had a late breakfast in the café. The bus takes you to the ICE Explorer, a specially designed vehicle with giant tires that can ride on glaciers. But all it does is drive you to a parking lot on the edge of the Athabasca glacier. Then you get off and walk in a restricted area. It’s cold and windy. 15 minutes is our time limit to take photos, get some glacier water and, hopefully, not fall through the ice. ICE Explorer back to the bus which takes us to the skywalk. This gives you a panoramic view of the glacier, but don’t attempt it if you have vertigo. There is also some information about the growth and decline of glaciers and flora and fauna info. Back on the bus to the parking lot and in the car for an hour and half drive to Lake Louise. I’d call it a once in a lifetime experience, because I certainly wouldn’t do it twice."

"Very interesting trip to the Columbia Ice Field. A large three-dimensional model of the Ice Field clearly shows its extent (100 square miles).You can also drive along the spur road, park and hike to the edge of the glacier, but don't venture onto the ice without a qualified guide - the crevasses are deep, & people have died in them."

"I didn't know where I could review the entire Icefields Parkway, so here it is. I downloaded the Gypsy App on my iPhone and wow, what fun. It covers the entire drive from Lake Louise to Jasper and back again. The app tracks where you are and tells you where to turn off to see the can't-miss sites and also which ones you CAN skip if you are short on time. I can't tell you how many great little hikes (e.g. Beauty Creek/Stanley Falls) that I would never have stopped for if it had not been for the app. It also tells you some of the history of the area as you are driving through. The entire Icefields Parkway is great, but the app made it so much better an experience. By the way, I did not do the glacier tour--I just hiked on the opposite side of the road to get close to the glacier. I just felt like the tour was too long a wait and too touristy, but I didn't go, so I can't speak from experience."

"This is a well-organized attraction, and one much in demand. Be sure you make a reservation ahead of time otherwise you'll be in for quite a wait.The registration center is equipped with indoor bathrooms, a restaurant, and a gorgeous viewing porch upstairs where you can wait for your turn to walk on the ice fields.First, you are taken by motorcoach up to the ice field staging area where you transfer to one of the mega-giant ice tractors. These machines are designed to withstand sub-zero temperatures and to crunch their way through ice with enough traction to avoid sliding. They transport you onto the ice field, where you can walk around and view the terrain close up. Unlike the pictures that look nice and smooth, the actual ice field is rough, with crevices and upheavals. In patches, you'll see the beautiful deep blue of the glacier ice beneath.I'm told most days you don't have to dress like NanNuk of the North, but our day was brutally cold! Blue-blue skies, puffy white clouds, and a wind that cut right through you. My recommendation? Wear layers, a hat, boots, and gloves."

"The Columbia Icefield is but one part of the whole Icefields Parkway. The actual icefield is a huge area overlapping a number of mountains. The Icefields Discovery Centre has an excellent movie available for free in the lower part of the center that introduces people to what it really is and how large it is.But the Parkway extends from Jasper to Lake Louise. There is a lot of beautiful scenery to take in, and you might see wildlife along the way. We saw a black bear. Other than the obvious Discovery Centre, there are various activities available there, and there are miles of hiking trails; everything from short and easy to overnight and rugged. Accommodations are limited, so booking in advance is critical if you are not camping or are in an RV. Technically, you could just park your car in many places and just ""wander off into the woods,"" but that is not a good idea! Bears abound, including grizzlies. Bear spray is good idea if you intend to go hiking inland, and it is recommended to hike with a group. (But if you hike a lot, you probably already know this.) There are many things, though, for the more touristy types. You can walk on a glacier (albeit for $80+!) You can walk up to a family friendly glacier viewpoint for free, across from the Discovery Centre. At places along the Parkway, are other viewpoints, stores, campgrounds, waterfalls, and scenery that almost overloads your senses. Everything you pay for is expensive, but the scenery is free. As for towns, Jasper is more low key than Lake Louise. I would recommend staying in Jasper if you can. If you want more of the ""icefields experience,"" then the Glacier View Inn is a good choice, but it is not easy to get in and out of. If you are a guest, parking is by the tourist buses, and you have to walk across a pedestrian bridge and through a crowded lobby to access it. Check in is 3 p.m. The rooms are not air conditioned, but are comfortable, and some have a loft, so they are family friendly. Prices are around $300 per night. Staff is helpful and friendly."
"Two visits - two days in a row. We did a drive from Jasper to take pics because the weather was clear. Took photos from the deck of the info centre. The following day was our drive from Jasper to Lake Louise so we stopped again, parking at the glacier carpark and walked up to the edge of the ice.Another sunny clear day and what a gorgeous sight."

"Stunning opportunity to be walking on the Columbia Ice Field and the associated glaciers. Involves multiple bus transfers in the price to actually motor up to the edge of the glacier. The glacier and the Ice Field is at about 7,000 feet and feels much colder with the wind blowing across the huge area of ice. (The Ice Field itself is about 200 square miles I believe, but you cannot see it all or walk on it all for sure.)This opportunity is clearly a time to make a change in your trip to visit and experience walking on a glacier. Due to climate change and the warming of the atmosphere driving the loss of the size of the glacier every year, this opportunity may not be there for more than five to ten years.Recommend highly that you make the time and committment to get here!"

"The Columbia Icefields is a must see part of Jasper National Park. The snow coaches are fun, the guides are informative and funny, and overall the experience was good. The Glacier itself is astonishing and the skywalk is....well..... it turns out I don't much care for see through wobbly-in-the-wind things sticking out of mountains but the adrenalin rush was fun. Those things being said, we did have what I consider a disproportionate number of issues, all of which seem to be relatively simple fixes. We were told upon booking that my father would need to present his credit card and possibly ID to receive our tickets. When we arrived the person requested the confirmation email and digital tickets, something hard to provide with no cell service (and as such no data or internet). I ended up going and borrowing the hotel's wifi to get the tickets, got back in line, got to the front after a 20 minute wait just to be told to go back to the back of the line and wait until 10 minutes before our departure time before entering the line again. Signage specifying what time slots are to be entering the line at any given time would be helpful as well as some clarity regarding how to get the tickets as some wires were crossed somewhere there. Boarding and the activities were all excellent. The last problem comes from our shuttle bus ride back to the Icefields Centre from the Skywalk. My parents, daughter, and I were the last people to board the bus and as such had to go all the way to the back. My mother has issues walking and balancing. The bus started moving before any of us were seated, the lurch causing my mother to fall into my daughter and throw her into the seat. My daughter spent the shuttle ride back crying which unfortunately ended the activity on a bit of a bum note. Should anyone affiliated with Brewster end up reading this please stress the importance to your staff of ensuring all people on the bus are seated before moving as a more severe injury could have easily happened or may happen in the future."

"If you have money to spend, book a ticket in advance in July and August take the tour! For budget friendly, stop in and check out the ice centre, but drive to the parking lot at the toe of the glacier and take the small hike to it. There is an uphill part but it's the only one and you can rest on the way. The path takes you to a better viewing area but not to the actual toe. A rope perimeter guides you so if you are adventurist, like ""breaking rules,"" and have lots of common sense, go under it and take the guides path to the toe. There are guided tours to it you can book with provided hiking boots and ice pick attachments, but on the bus tour you walk on the glacier with no special equipment. Cross a wooden plank over a narrow path of rushing water and step foot on the Columbia Glacier. Don't venture far just walk a few feet on and check it out. Ice crevices are narrow but slippery and can go 100's of feet into the ice. You don't want to fall down one as that's where you will stay. The ice field area is colder but even more so on the glacier plus quite windy. On the bus tour, guided tour or on your own, wear pants, a warm coat, take something to cover your ears and bring Kleenex (as your nose will likely run) and water."

You take a greyhound style bus up to the glacier and then onto a special bus to transport you onto the glacier. At the glacier, you'll have about 30min to walk/slide around and take photos or get water. Our bus took a load of guests to the Skywalk before unloading us back at the visitor centre. Tips: dress warm (it's freezing!) Wear grippy shoes, bring a water bottle to fill up"

"I highly recommend this place if you're visiting Banff or Jasper. If you're looking for a hiking experience that is inexpensive, this is not the right place for you. However, this is the perfect place for those who want to have the experience of walking on a glacier. It's a once-in-a-lifetime experience. You will save some money (cheaper than if you buy it there) you book online 48 hours in advance (10% discount in addition). Make sure you bring some warm clothes, especially extra socks. It's easy to get wet. It gets a bit chilly, especially with the wind. If you have snowshoes, that would be ideal, as that will help you walk around with slipping like everyone else. Imagine walking on an uneven frozen pond. Bring some empty water bottles to fill up from the glacier stream. Overall, this is an amazing experience."

"Walking on a glacier is a truly once in a lifetime opportunity!We took our two daughters - 12 and 16 on this tour, and we could not believe ourselves, as it exceeded (all) our expectations!Be sure to book ahead, or you may end up missing this memorable experience of driving and walking on a glacier. Our trip started at the Columbia Ice Field Visitor Center, where there's plenty of parking for cars and/or RVs. After admiring the glacier views from afar, we queued up for the tour. At first you board a bus for a short drive to a private (inaccessible) parking lot, where you board a giant 6x6 vehicle/Ice Bus. This truck/bus is an experience in its own, but it is definitely not the highlight of your trip. You will be driving up to a glacier passing through ice, down a 30 degrees descent (a bit scary at first), and then onto a glacier. The bus will offload you, and let you roam free on the ice, where you can take amazing pictures, play with snow balls, or touch the water, which are at almost freezing temperature. We were dressed with fleece jackets, as it was quite chilly on the ice. This is a highly recommended experience for all ages!"

Jasper national park has some amazing places, and I encourage you to explore by car, but do not fall victim to the tourist traps. The bathroom had human feeces chunked all over the toilet seat, likely from the common way that some people from other countries squat over a toilet seat instead of using it the way it should be used. I felt so bad for the guys waiting outside to go in and clean the bathroom. The gift shop sold Chapstick for $6, t-shirts for $89 and sweatpants for $60. Needless to say it's a rip off, all for looking at a chunk of dirty snow. There are so many other beautiful places in Canada and I encourage you to visit them. "Last time I felt like how I felt today was stuffed in a tram in Disney World...I've visited the icefield centre 16 years ago. That time you would have maybe 3 ice explorers on the glacier... these days Brewster pack the glacier with 8-10 ice explorers at a time. Good luck racing up the tiny area to get your expensive selfie. The scoop is: it is one of these experiences you should do once in your life, so plan ahead. DO NOT come here on a nice weekend this summer. It is insane. Plan ahead and book your tickets online around 48 hrs in advance. You would get 10% discount (wow). Plan to arrive 45 min before your departure, this will give you time to line up to the washroom ( no soap?), line up to the gift shop , then you can line up to your designated 'adventure'. We did not do the skywalk, it looks pretty dumb. It is a cantilevered semi circled bridge they built above the canyon ( no relation to the glacier or Columbia icefield), 8 minutes drive from the centre. There is a bus ride from the centre to the ice explorer loading zone. The ice explorer takes you up to the glacier (Athabasca glacier, part of Columbia Icefield). You get 20 minutes on the ice, then loaded back to the ice explorer, back to a bus , then priority is given to the ones who wasted more money and the bus then first drive to the skywalk, drop off and then back to the centre...Does it worth $270 for a family of four? No. The icefield area is gorgeous, and has nothing to do with Brewster. They have over-commercialized this place, squeezed every possible profit imaginable. Unfortunately, there is no other safe way to get to the glacier. I am not sure how a private company is allowed to own a piece of nature, in the middle of a NATIONAL park."

"OK, you don't really get to see the Columbia Icefield.That's a cluster of glaciers flowing from a high point over the top of the skyscraping mountains. What you get is a view of some of those glaciers as they pour slowly over the rim of the mountains. And a beautiful trip along the Icefields Parkway, one of the most beautiful drives in the world. You also get an entertaining ride on a six-wheel drive all-terrain bus, unique to this place, that takes you out onto the lower part of the glacier where you can walk around and drink the glacier meltwater if you like. Highly recommended."
"Brewster has the Ice Field tours sewn up, which, when you hear the drivers' spiel, is understandable once you've learned that the vehicles cost 1.3 million dollars, and the 6 tires cost $4K/each and only last 2 or 3 seasons. But the drivers' patter also goes toward geological explanation of what is being seen, a sense of history (in 1843 the Glacier filled the whole valley, and will disappear in 150 years) as well as a lot of jokes to spackle the parts together. Once we reached the glacier, we were given about 20 minutes to walk on a relatively small, restricted area, although that seemed long enough for most of the busload. The cost is high, and it would probably be sounder ecologically to walk up on foot, but it looks as if Brewster's 22 buses will continue to shuffle back and forth for a long time to come."
We were on a bus tour and one of the stops was to drive onto the glacier in a special buggy. The temperatures are 10 degrees colder than on the roadside and do take warm clothes. There is a special group you can book to hike over the glacier with a guide and this would be worth doing.The glacier is melting and is regressing at several meters each year and the surface is cut into by channels of melt water. The edge of the glacier where melting has been fastest is surrounded by gravel and moraine and provides an excellent example of the typical glacial landscape.

"First, I recommend booking this online ahead of time. The Discovery Center where all tours depart from is very crowded and overall not well organized. We had pre-purchased tickets, but we were taking a chance on the weather since tickets are not refundable. If you do purchase ahead of time be sure to print out both the tickets and the boarding pass - this isn't clear and it was just lucky I had both.The overall tour takes about 3 hours, and everything is very punctual. This tour includes both a ride to the glacier and the skywalk. You board one of the ""Ice Explorer"" buses to ride out to the glacier itself. You then have about 20 minutes to walk around on the ice. It's brief, but the area that you are walk on is very small. It is a glacier, so it will be cold, so be prepared, even in on a warmer day. After the glacier visit, you ride the Ice Explorer back and then board another bus which takes you to the Skywalk - a short drive down the road. You drive past the Skywalk on the Icefields Parkway, but cannot stop there yourself, you must purchase tickets and take the bus. I'm not sure exactly why it's called a Glacier Skywalk - it is not over a glacier, but over a valley. You walk a short distance down a path along the road to the skywalk and then walk out on the glass walkway. You the board the bus back to the Discovery Center to end the tour. You spend much of the time riding to and from and the young staff members make an effort to be informative, fun, and entertaining."
"We took the icefield skywalk package and was in complete awe of how efficient it was run.we started our day early from Banff ended up getting there early so we had time for breakfast in the lodge where you depart from we were pleasantly surprised at how yummy everything was and not to over priced. The bused to the icefield to hop on a jumbo icefield bus which took us on an informative and exciting trip onto the icefield. Then it was fantastic being on the icefield drinking the glacier water and taking in this wonderful piece of nature, we actually saw a piece break off and the noise was so loud - so exciting. A must see in ones lifetime! Sky walk is a genius engineering feat, very cool and informative we loved every minute of this tour."

"The Glacier Tour was fun! The size of the glacier is amazing, even knowing that it has receded so much. There is a bit of a climb, meaning it’s tougher to walk up, but much easier going down. Keep in mind that this glacier is melting because of the ebbs and flows of nature; other glaciers in the area are actually building up and getting larger over time. Please also be mindful not to go outside the roped areas for safety reasons. "What if I told you that, for just a relatively small price increase over the price of a regular tour, you could cut down crowds by 96%, eat high-end hors d'oeuvres on the glacier, and have a fairly good buffet dinner -- ALL INCLUDED in the price?You'd tell me I'm crazy, right?Well, if you want to experience the Columbia Icefield glacier in a high-end environment, free of crowds and hassle, for a great price, read on...Like many of you, the thought of riding a unique vehicle up to the glacier, and then walking on it (and drinking pure water from it) sounded appealing.Like many of you, the thought of waiting on long lines, crowding into a bus, and standing shoulder-to-shoulder with 400 people on the glacier was NOT appealing.I almost skipped this ""adventure"", until I read a review of a very NEW product offered by the same company (Brewster) from the same location.At 5:30pm and 6:30pm every night, they run an ""Evening on the Ice"" program. It typically has only about 16-20 people total (our group had 16). Compare this to 400-500 people on the glacier at once in the normal tours, this is already a MASSIVE improvement.While on the glacier, each person gets some tasty hors d'oeuvres, packaged in metal boxes. After about 30 minutes on the glacier, they bring you back to the lodge, where you have a private buffet dinner, which is pretty good as far as buffets go.The entire experience is high-end and personal. The guides even come have dinner with everyone, and walk around asking if anyone has further questions.All of the guides, including driver Bruce, were very knowledgeable, friendly, and accessible.This experience sounds like it would cost at least 5-10 times more than the regular tour. After all, they're sending up 96% FEWER people to the glacier, and also serving you both appetizers and dinner (neither of which are given at the regular tour). Instead, the price points are VERY CLOSE -- only about $25 more per person!Can you believe it? You get SO MUCH MORE by paying only a little more.The regular Columbia Icefield tour seems like a crowded cattle herding, while Evening on the Ice is how you'd picture the rich people doing it -- except you don't have to be rich to afford it!I suggest doing this soon, because I am assuming they will either end this or massively raise the price after 2017. This just started in mid-June, 2017, and is ""experimental"" right now.I promise you will not be sorry if you do this.A few tips:- Go at 6:30. Will still be plenty light enough, but I think the 5:30 tour still ran into some of the ""end of day"" regular glacier tours (not sure, but that's what it looked like). At our 6:30 tour, we were the only ones up there. It was so nice and peaceful!- WEAR WARM CLOTHES. It is about 38 degrees up there with a cold wind blowing up the ice. It will feel like 15-20 degrees. Do not be deceived by the warm temperatures at the lodge.- Bring an empty bottle (any empty bottle) to collect glacier water. It is clean, drinkable, and tastes GREAT.- This tour is right in between Jasper and Banff, so it's close to nothing. Make sure to plan your day well, and time it properly so you don't miss it!- Buy your tickets in advance -- preferably at least a month.- Evening on the Ice does NOT include the SkyWalk, but honestly, you're not missing much, and can also do it separately if you really feel like you want to do it.While this was an excellent experience overall, if I can offer the company a few tips for improvement (they read this), it would involve the buffet. The buffet, while good overall, is a bit disorganized and seemingly makes some rookie mistakes. They ran out of plates fairly often, the chicken was constantly running out and being replaced a few at a time, and the prime rib both ran out and was immediately cold when replaced. This needs a few tweaks to operate a bit better, but you're on the right track. Overall, Evening on the Ice is a great product!"

"The ride along the parkway is scenic but you cannot see much from the parkway. To actually see the Ice field you must take the Brewster attraction tour. Fifteen years ago my husband and I went to Alaska. We took a helicopter ridge out to a glacier. We walked on the glacier. The company took great care to not bring any external dirt onto the glacier. They provided boots and parkas. They also enforced staying safe. It was incredible. So I really wanted to see the Columbia Ice field. Unfortunately, Brewster is not taking the precautions to avoid outside contamination. Yes, they wash the wheels of the vehicles that go out to the ice field but as for other contamination from shoes, they don't seem to care. Given the number of vehicles and thus people out on the glacier, between grit and other contamination, they are hastening the loss of the glacier. Anyone who has used salt on ice and snow knows, anything not pure water will lower the melting point of the ice. It does not matter what the substance is just how many particles are present. This is basic science and is called freezing point depression. Grit will wear the ice down through friction. Given the sheer number of people walking on a small area of the glacier, there are a lot of particles and grit added each day. As for keeping people within the safe area to protect them, in the 30 minutes out there, there were more people outside the red cones than in. Our guide explained the danger before we were let out on the ice, but none of the guides did anything to stop anyone from either being or sending their children out to get better pictures."
"Take the Sno Coach ride onto the Athabasca Glacier to walk on a glacier that will only be here for another 100 years. A bus takes you from the Discovery Center to the transfer site where you board a Sno Coach which takes you onto the glacier. Watch your step! Ice is melting and some people got wet by stepping in a hole and some fell down. Drivers are informative while narrating the trip. The Discovery Center has rest rooms, gift shops, and cafeterias but be warned, food prices are steep. The skywalk is a unique glass walk built out over a river valley far below and it offers beautiful views of waterfalls, river, and mountains."

"So AWESOME!!! We camped in Canmore and drove to the Glacier Discovery Centre.We had just heard about the tour, so we didn't know you could get discounted tickets 48 hours ahead online. The water in the many streams was really good, some people put some into their water bottles. The view was breathtaking!!! I was hesitant at first to walk on the Skywalk, but Pat told us it can hold the wait of 3 Ice Explorers. First we looked down while walking, but that was scary so we walked than looked down. We walked the whole thing and talked to Jessica, an employee. She asked if we wanted our picture taken on the Skywalk. She used our camera and took several great pictures, thank you Jessica. Buses come every 15 min., so you leave when you want back to the Centre. This tour is for any age, use the washroom just before boarding the bus from the Centre.We live in Idaho and plan on going back again this year."

"We drove for one hour and fifteen minutes from our hotel in Jasper, luckily found a black bear on the way roaming near the road and kids loved it. You pass the glacier skywalk before reach the Columbia Ice field Discovery Center, although the skywalk was highly recommended by our Conceirge but except the glass floor which gives shivers to some nothing to write home about it and luckily we saved both time and money. There is ample parking at the discovery center and in summer the operate till 6pm and we got our tickets on the spot but I will advise advance Booking. First we boarded a regular bus that took us to the base camp which is like a kilometer from Discovery Center, there we boarded a special bus with High wheelbase and the amazing journey started. It takes you down the steepest road in North America with a 35 degree descent. On the way down,You can tell the glacier is melting fast unfortunately due to global warming. After a kilometer long but a slow ten minutes ride we reach the glacier and disembarked. Its breathtaking once you come out and don't forget to take empty water bottles so you can bring home some at source glacial water. It's really dangerous on the glacier so you have to walk slowly one step at time and stay away from marked holes and within the boundary and hold the hands of younger children all the time. We were allowed to spend around 10-15 minutes but it was more than enough before anxiety starts to bother one."

"If the weather is clear - you NEED to take this adventure. Our driver Mattie made the short drive out n the tracker quite enjoyable and informative. When you get out on the glacier notice the colors of the snow, ice and water!. We filled our water bottles with glacier water - incredible taste and clarity- don't drink too much too quickly -your body may not be used to such purity. Even with other people around - it was like walking on another planet . Imagine -- that ice was formed thousands and thousands of years ago ! Breathe in the clear mountain air ....fantastic. Dress in layers - if the wind comes up it can get quite cool - if the sun is beating down you need sunscreen....and wear proper shoes or walking boots . You will be walking on snow and ice ."

"This was one of the highlights of my two week trip to Canada. Not many people can say they have experienced Summer and Winter in the same week! We stopped off here on the way from Jasper to Banff and went up onto the ice field on the big wheeled busses. Never before have i seen anything like it so the ride onto the ice was a thrill in itself. Our driver (I think his name was Patrick, i may be wrong) was very informative engaging and funny. I was slipping and sliding all over the ice field and was clinging onto my friend for dear life, so wear sturdy shoes. I wore VANS which i presumed would have grip, maybe its just me though. The only word I can use to describe the ice field itself is beautiful! I filled up my water bottle from the ice cold, crystal clear stream and it was the best water i ever tasted. Tip - Wrap up warm and take sunglasses, its very bright on the ice! Take a water bottle to fill up too!"

"We are in Jasper for a couple of nights on an organised Saga holiday from UK through to Calgary, Banff, Jasper, Rocky Mountaineer and cruise to Alaska. We stopped off here on our way to Jasper. It depends on your point of view.You are taken by coach and ""Ice Explorer"" up onto the Glacier where you spend around 15 minutes on the glacier taking photos and looking at the scenery. Some would say @what was the point of that? My view was the experience of standing on a moving river of ice, realising that it is slowly melting glacier (tho not slow enough), and realising also how mankind is unable to prevent it, apart from controlling his likely contribution toward it.There is no doubt that as it is privately owned it is commercial. However by encouraging Joe Public to go on this one, he is not helping to further destroy other glaciers.I found it an aweinspiring experience, not much there, not long on it but wonderful nevertheless. You choose, look at it from a distance or take the opportunity presented."

"This is a ""must-experience"" for many reasons, the most obvious being the startling grandeur and splendour of this magnificent ares. The second reason is to see for yourself how the great glaciers – especially Athabasca Glacier – has receded over the past 150 years, giving unmistakeable proof of global warming. It used to be a raw place to visit with few amenities and some of us liked it that way, but now it is efficient and civilized: you can get up on the glacier easily by paying a fare, though they don't take you high enough to see the actual icefields. For that you might need to climb Mt Athabasca as I did nearly 40 years ago. Caution, this area is highly congested traffic-wise, and you are asked not to feed the often-numerous wildlife (especially bighorn sheep) that still come down to graze by the road. Snowstorms can suddenly appear out of nowhere."

You can fall into crevasses and serious injuries can result. Stay off the ice at the toe of the glacier and just enjoy it before it is gone. It is the only public easily-accessible glacier in the Rockies."

"We have driven on this highway a few times but the wonderful sights and vistas of Rocky mountains never cease to amaze.Long sections of the highway are marked as ""Avalanche Country"" or prone to avalanche induced closure in late winter and spring. AS it happened on our last trip, we set out from Jasper to go to Lake Louis and return travelling both ways on highway 93, Icefields Parkway.The outward journey was great,Sights were beautiful and there was not much traffic. On the return trip, about an hours drive on the Parkway towards Jasper, we were stopped and told to turn around as the highway was closed due to an avalanche!We had to turn around and limp into Rocky Mountain house on last few drops of fuel. Lessons learned; don't step on Icefield Parkway unless you have a full tank of gas; AND, do not plan an essential journey on this road from late winter to late spring.Our adventure found us stranded in Rocky Mountain House hundreds of kilometers from our luggage and a paid-up hotel room. But still, a memorable trip."

"THIS IS A REVIEW OF COLUMBIA ICEFIELD. PUT REVIEWS OF ATHABASCA GLACIER, THE ICE EXPLORER, THE ICEFIELD GLACIER DISCOVERY CENTER, and THE ICEFIELD PARKWAY UNDER THOSE HEADINGS, NOT THIS ONE.The Columbia Icefield is the biggest in the North American Rockies. It is part in Alberta to the east and British Columbia to the west, part in Jasper National Park to the north and Banff National Park to the south. It feeds hundreds of glaciers, lakes and waterfalls. It is massive and over a thousand feet thick in ice created over the milliennia. Attempting to walk, hike or cross it is prohibited, because there is no way you can be rescued. You can glimpse it on the peaks along the Icefields Parkway. The closest most of us can get to it is by taking the tour of the Athabasca Glacier on the Ice Explorer, at the Icefield Glacier Discovery Center on the Icefields Parkway, Highway 93."

"You can experience much about the Athabasca Glacier without taking the expensive buses onto the glacier. You can park on the glacier side of the road and walk up to near the bottom of the glacier. Make sure you wrap up well before getting out of the car as there is a fierce wind that seems to blow most of the way up to the glacier. Once at the glacier bottom it is much calmer. Also make sure you wear adequate footwear as part of the climb is steep and covered with stones / shale that can slip. I saw some ladies picking there way on the downward path wearing only flip-flops!!! Silly. Remember the altitude is nearly 2000m and so some people may be short of breath. You can't get super near the end of the glacier as there are potential crevass hazards, so its worth obeying the signs. If you have a good camera with a good zoom lens, you can see a lot of the overhanging glaciers and ice fields, which is fun. We only spent about 30 mins looking at the glacier as it was cold. Another tip - make sure you do not need to visit the loo as they only have a cabin with the hole-in-the - ground style on the glacier side of the road. There are full facilities on the other side. Definitely a must-do thing, but be well prepared."

"Of all the various places we went to while in Alberta on our recent trip to Canada, this has to be up there as one of the top and most memorable excursions.We went up on to the glacier on one of the many specially designed buses that run between the glacier and the nearby visitor centre. Our tour guide, who was a geology student at the University of Alberta in Edmonton, certainly knew her stuff and provided just the right mix of a sense of humour and knowledge to make what might otherwise have been, but for the scenery, a simple, if bumpy at times, 'bus trip', into something much more fun and interesting.On the glacier itself (do wrap up - it's cold up there!), we were limited to a relatively small area for the immense number of people up there at any one time. The environmentalist in me was pleased at this but this was at odds with the tourist factor! However, it served its purpose and with a couple of well placed Canadian flags together with super-ancient ice up close, there were some excellent photo opportunities. We also filled our drinking bottle up with glacial water, which is one of the things to do up there. I am however unsure whether to recommend this as lovely (and cold!) as the water was, my gut appeared to disagree with it several hours later. Whether it was the water or something else I can't be sure - but I'd be wary doing it again!This is something I think you'd probably do just the once rather than repeatedly - but it is absolutely worth doing. It is without any shadow of a doubt, super touristy and there is no question that the company behind this operation squeeze every possible dollar our of the thousands of visitors. Personally I'd prefer fewer buses going up onto the glacier at any one time but this is never going to happen when there is so much money to be made.I strongly suggest a visit during either the Spring or Autumn 'shoulder' seasons. July, although sunny, was surely the peak period for tourists. Lovers of animals and nature risk being disappointed if in the general area to see wildlife. This is as true of this location as others such as Banff and Jasper at this time of year. The sheer volume of people these days pushes the wildlife to other locations. Even the national parks seemed very liberally populated with anything other than human beings.Recommended and slickly operated - just *massively* touristy. As others have said - go as early as possible."
"A bit touristy, no doubt... but I still don't regret spending the extra $$ for this. So if you happen to be in the neighborhood and have never done so before, it is worth trying once at least.And the coach that took us there was cool too.Like some other reviewers, I was also left with a little feeling of sadness knowing that the glaciers will be gone in 100 years.Nothing lasts forever, so enjoy it while it lasts."

"It would be hard not to stop if passing anyway but I would encourage anyone visiting either Jasper or Bamff to make the round trip to the Columbia ice fields. The scenery in the Rockies national parks is so spectacular from the road that the hidden interiors of the ranges: the glaciated, barren ridges and razor peaks obscured behind the lush forests and eye catching lower rocky peaks. If you are visiting the mountains by car (and good for you, it's a great way to see the country), the drive up to the ice fields is really the only chance to see this high-altitude landscape. The terrifying pace this glacier is retreating is another reason to see this for yourself. So impressive still in scale is the remaining portion that it is hard to imagine the glacier 100 years ago pouring out of this valley and branching out north and south down the great central spine of the Rockies. The climate here is changing, and at a pace and scale that you will see firsthand at few other places on earth."

"If you have never been on a glacier, or seen one up close, and are not particularly adventuresome, this might be worth the drive and the price ($85 per adult/$43 per child over 6). A minimum drive of two hours from anywhere, the ice fields are fairly close to the main road. Perhaps having had the experience of being on another glacier gave us a jaded view of what we saw here, but this is more of a drive-by experience with about thousand other folks who just happen to be traveling on a packaged bus tour. The first stop is the ticket window in an overcrowded lodge a couple of kilometers to the east. After that, plan on waiting upwards to an hour or two until you are loaded on a regular bus for the ride over to the ice field where you will then transfer to an ""Ice Bus"" that will slowly take you out onto the glacier before depositing you on the ice for a while. Getting there, waiting and visiting the glacier for about half an hour will consume an entire day. The main lodge provides a mediocre selection of extremely overpriced food while you wait for your tour to begin. You can also purchase an additional ticket to visit the Glacier Skywalk that is a few kilometers up the highway and requires another bus ride to get to (cars are not allowed), and since this glass skywalk venue is not over the ice, the term ""glacier"" seems a bit misleading at best and at $32 per adult it seems grossly over-priced. Too touristy for us, but draw your own conclusions. We feel that there are far better options for using your time when visiting Jasper National Park."

"We rode the Ice Explorer onto the glacier as part of a Sun Dog Tour. Because we were on a tour our spots were reserved on the explorer so there was no waiting. "We were taken here as part of a tour, and while the bus ride with commentary to the glacier itself is interesting, it is fascinating to actually walk on one. I was concerned it might be slippery, but just took care and wore boots with a good sole, however one senior gentleman had a bad fall on the ice. I don't know if the buses career to those in wheelchairs or on walkers, but it would be extremely challenging I would think. I do worry what all the constant bus activity is doing to the glacier. It can't be good. The major downside is that our only lunch option was to eat at the Icefields tourist centre, which was a zoo. Simply too many people to make it a comfortable experience. If you suffer from crowd anxiety or claustrophobic, which I don't, I'd give this a miss. The food was awful and expensive, but this is the middle of nowhere. I'd recommend you pack a lunch and use the toilets only."

"Firstly, there appears to be some confusion, about what reviews under this subject heading relate to. I understand this to relate to the Columbia Icefield and not experiences relating to trips on to the Columbia Glacier by ""Ice Explorer"" vehicle, which are probably more appropriately reviewed under ""Columbia Icefield Glacier Adventure"". The Ice Field glacier is easily seen from the Icefields Parkway road and information is available in the Discovery Centre on the opposite side of the road. The area and depth of the snow/ice are quite staggering to those of us that live in more temperate regions. Disappointing is the fact that changes in climate are resulting in the size of the glacier reducing gradually each year. Is this inflicted by the human race? Whilst glaciers can be seen elsewhere the extent of this Ice Field is truly impressive. A major feature of the Icelands Parkway"

On our way up to the Athabasca Glacier we met a woman from Minnesota, who was carrying a photo from 1973 of where the snout of the glacier was at that time--all the way to the present parking lot. A visit here will expand your consciousness about the age of our planet and our collective responsibility to steward it wisely."

A few years ago during an Alaskan Cruise I had the opportunity to view a glacier. Viewing the Columbia Icefields and the Athabasca Glacier was so very different and better! The Discovery Centre imparts a lot of information about the glacier formation as well as the melting of it. As a visitor you can purchase a ticket to ride a tundra buggy on the glacier and walk on it. Some tour companies schedule walking tours on the glacier. If neither appeals to you then you can drive your vehicle to the parking lot adjacent to the glacier and take a short but challenging hike to the base of it. Along the way you see signs where the glacier extended at that point in time. One really gets a sense of how much ice has melted and how much the glacier has receded.Well over 100 years ago the glacier extended across the main road to the Discovery Centre. AMAZING! Much like the Skywalk this is a must see!

"My wife and I visited the ice field on 13/09. We were on a Rocky Mountaineer tour with Brewsters, so once our driver had secured our tickets, we were transported up to the SnoCoach terminal and were soon being directed to one of specially built coaches.We were transported on to the glacier on coach 543, which was driven by Connor. He did a wonderful job of explaining the geology and science of the area, the glaciers, plus the development and performance characteristics of the coach.It's when you discover where the ice was in 1840 (the location of the centre by the Icefields Parkway) and how 2 other glaciers (including the one coming off Mt Andromeda) used to feed into the main Athabasca one, that you realise how much climate change and global warming has effected our planet.We were allowed to step off the bus and explore the safe area that had been marked out for visitors to get the feel of a glacier beneath their feet.Although it is very commercialised and regimented, this attraction offers us 'non-explorer' types the opportunity to walk on a glacier and to learn how it has been created and moves.Safety tip - please make sure you take some warm clothes, decent shoes, sunglasses and sunscreen."

There are two ways to view the icefield: 1) you can park in the car park thats on the same side of the road as the glacier and walk towards it. You can view the glacier from here but you cannot walk on it. 2) if you can afford the $90 ticket you can reach the icefield via the tour run from the information centre. This includes a bus from the centre up to the side of the glacier and then a ride on the ice explorer on to the glacier. Here you can get off and walk on the glacier. Included in your ticket is access to the sky walk. Would highly recommend doing the tour as the guides were very informative and it is really well organised. However if you are on a budget it is still possible to enjoy the beauty of the glacier from a distance.

"The Columbia Icefield is located in the southern end of Jasper National Park in the Canadian Rockies. It is the largest expanse of ice outside of the Arctic. Six main glaciers make up this ""field."" Because the area is situated on the Continental Divide, the melt from these glaciers flows into the Pacific, Atlantic, AND Arctic Oceans; feeding fresh water systems as far away as the Hudson Bay, Columbia River, and more. The Athabasca glacier is the most accessible one to this field. This glacier is rapidly shrinking in volume and receding at a current rate of approximately 16 feet per year. As the ice retreats, it leaves behind a moonscape of gravel and rock. This barren scape is enhanced by the surreal blue of glacial veins -- a combination that makes for some great photo opportunities. This is a fairly easy glacier to access, but the weather in the field is unpredictable and can be difficult. For example, on this day we were sporadically accompanied by high winds, vast silences, and various forms of precipitation (snow, ice, rain)."
We did the Columbia Ice Field tour and really enjoyed it. Not too often do you get to walk on an ice field without having to take a helicopter to experience it. Here you ride on buses outfitted with large wheels to safely get you onto the ice field. We walked around and filled our water bottles with ice cold glacier water. It was a once in a lifetime experience not to be missed.

"th eColumbia Icefield feeds 5 glaciers - you should see the amount of snow and ice that has piled up - around 150 years back, the glacier was where the parking lots are now - it is sad to see it receding. But the view is worth it."

The Icefield was part of a small package we put together and at first I thought it would be hokey and too touristy. The gathering building is new and they quickly shuttled us via bus to the glacier. Once there we boarded the huge snow-cat type bus for the interesting ride to the glacier. Steep up and down hills both ways. Good education on the glacier and the sad story of the continued shrinking of the glacier.Once on the glacier we had about 30 cold minutes. You are in a valley so the winds whip down over acres of ice and the temps are much lower than the parking lot. You are on a glacier - frozen water - aka ice. You will slip unless you are in some sort of solid hiking shoe or boot. The lady in the Coach sneakers learned the hard way.Great pics. Get them while there is still something to see.

We didn't go on the ice explorer, but I've heard that is a pretty cool experience and the visitor center is very nice as well."

"This is a must stop on the Ice Field Parkway. You get a glimpse of the ice field but what you really get a good view of is the Athabasca Glacier. The Visitor Center will be crowded with buses and RV's, but if you've never seen a glacier this is the place to get some background. From the Visitor Center drive across the road over to the parking lot. You can walk about 500 yards uphill from a parking lot and get great views of the glacier. But if you have the time and want the experience there are glacier walking tours. I've walked and climbed on glaciers so we didn't do this here. But if you've never be on ice-do the tour. You'll get good information about the history of glaciers and their disappearance and of course a walk on the ice. The last time I was here was 1982. The ice has retreated almost 1/2 mile since then. Climate change is real and in case you have any doubts a visit to the Athabasca Glacier will change your mind."

"Not having done our homework beforehand, we arrived at the glacier center and almost made the massive mistake of buying one of the glacier bus tours, only to find out that the ice walk portion of the tour was at the driver's discretion and ""may not happen."" Luckily, we pressed the staff person and found out that twice daily, a separate company (a fantastic local company, not a huge corporation like Brewster), runs ice walks that actually involved guiding walking tours of the glacier and all the ice features on it. Under our awesome guide's supervision, we looked inside crevasses, drank glacier water, learned about all the features and larger ecosystem of the glacier, and had a tremendous up-close experience with this incredible natural feature, which is rapidly disappearing. Don't fall for the fancy marketing-- make sure you ask about the Althabasca Ice Walks!"

Yes the structure is an interesting piece of engineering but it felt like an unnecessary detour and standing on a glass floor isn't that exciting. "I visited the Athabasca glacier 55 years ago when I was 13 years old and it was sad to see how much the glacier has receded over the years. Despite this, the glacier it is a most wonderful site. We did an icewalk tour which was a most incredible experience (see my review). As well, we stayed in the RV campground/parking lot, across the road for three nights. This 'campground' during the daytime is simply a parking lot, but a few RVers stay overnight - about 12 each of the three nights that we were there. Self-registration is $15.70; cash or credit card. It is unserviced but is next to the Icefields Discovery Centre which has a cafeteria, restaurant, washrooms (no showers), and a Parks Canada Information booth with free WiFi. There is no cell phone coverage in the area, but there are pay phones. The views of the Athabasca glacier are spectacular - the glacier is across the road!!!"

"While I have seen glaciers quite a few times, this was my first opportunity to walk on one. How exciting! It was very, very busy and the tickets are times so that if you arrive at 1 pm, you might not get to go out on the glacier until 3 pm. So go early especially if you have any time deadlines. "The Ice Field Parkway extends from Lake Louise to Jasper, and is full of wonderful views of mountains, rivers, lakes, waterfalls, wildlife and of course, the Columbia Ice Field. The ice field is about 2/3 of the way....a pretty long way to do up and back in the same day, so if is usally done in conjunction with an overnight in Jasper, and then drive back south the next day.The ice field can be seen from the parkway, or from the visitors center, or through various hikes, but many people book the tour which drives out on the glacier, and you can get out for a while and walk on the glacier. I have done that, and it is ok. Bare in mind during the busy season you may have to wait a couple of hours for the next tour with openings. It is also possible to book in advance. There are 3 glacier areas, one on the mountain to the left, one on the mountain to the right, and the glacier in the valley between them. The tour goes out on the glacier in the valley.This is a fairly unique experience....so go do it!"

"There are a few places in the world to see glaciers, but most are melting, so it's worth a stop and checking out. The Columbia Ice Field center is very nice, complete with a cafe and bathrooms. There are 2 parking lots....one by the center and one down by the glacier with only one ""outhouse"" type toilet and quite a long line, so I recommend taking care of any needs in the center, then drive down to the glacier. Be prepared for a bit of a walk, the glacier has melted back some. There are 3 ways to go see it....hire a guide for a hike up the glacier, ride the big monster bus, or walk up to it by yourself. People walking up to it on their own had to cross a rope at some point if they wanted to actually put their feet onto the glacier itself. Once you cross the rope, you would need crampons, and a lot of care as there are crevasses in the ice one could fall into and never be seen again."

"There are two options to walk on the glacier at the Columbia Ice Field. One is to buy a ticket, ride a shuttle to the ice vehicles, then ride the Ice Explorer vehicles up onto the glacier. On the glacier, you get off the Ice Explorer vehicle and walk around for 15-30 minutes. The second option is to drive to a parking spot across the road from the Columbia Icefield Visitor Center, then hike about 500 yards/meters uphill to the glacier. We did the former and did not do the latter. From the visitor center you can see both options and decide, and you can also drive to the parking spot to better view the trail difficulty for the second option. Or, you can do both.Make sure you read the website regarding the dangers of walking on a glacier. You must stay within the boundaries the park has marked safe. http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/pn-np/ab/jasper/activ/explore-interets/glacier-athabasca.aspxIf you are considering buying a ticket, you should review your plans, as there are combination packages that may save you some money. For example, You can buy a ticket to go only on the Glacier Skywalk. However, if you buy a ticket to go onto the glacier via the shuttle and Ice Explorer vehicle, that ticket includes the Glacier Skywalk. There is no option to buy a ticket only for the Ice Explorer vehicle trip. So decide what you are going to do before you buy. There are other optional combinations with boat and gondola rides in Banff and Jasper.We arrived about 10:45 am on Wednesday 17 August and were able get two tickets for the 11:45 am Ice Explorer Option.I write these reviews to help other travelers. If you find this review helpful, please let me know so that I continue to write them. Thank you."
"My family enjoyed the visit to the Columbia Ice Field. "We took the Athabasca Ice Fields walk in the afternoon when we we staying in Jasper area and glad we did. Many years ago I had taken a great hike on a glacier in Glacier Ntl Park so I thought it would be similar to that but it wasn't . This glacier is very crusty on the top and doesn't have the crevices like the one I hiked before. This felt safer than the prior one. It was interesting to see the rivers flowing down the glacier making designs in the ice similar to what one sees in places like Maligne Canyon. There were other interesting things to see such as the ice cave and a huge hole (moulin) with water flowing into it. We much preferred walking on the ice than taking the cat up and standing in the one limited area those folks were limited to. Information was shared on the tour but it would have been nice to have even more information about the glacier and the geology of the area than what was given. As a side note this company will provide hats, gloves, jackets and even boots if you need them. It does get windy up on the glacier but just regular hiking slacks were fine and 2 layers of wick aways and a wind jacket with hat and gloves worked fine. Enjoy!"

"The Columbia Ice fields are amazing to see up close. The walk up to the glacier is cold and takes you through the materials left behind by the glacier. Once there you feel as though you are in a whole different world. Barren rock surrounded by numerous inukshuk's built by fellow visitors. The retreat of the glacier is tracked over time by signs posting the dates of past positions. It was very enlightening to see this record of the past. Access to the base of the glacier is free, however you have to pay for a tour to get onto the glacier. My best piece of advice, bring your own food. There are only two restaurants in the visitors centre nearby and they are very pricy. I mean $30 per person for a Chinese buffet pricey."

"We decided to skip out on the tour bus onto the glacier and instead took the ""toe of the glacier"" hike up to the base of the glacier. You can't actually step onto the glacier with this hike unless you take a guided tour (not sure if they're free?), which I was disappointed in as I was led to believe you could step onto it, but you do get some close up photos. It is dangerous though so I understand why people aren't allowed on it. There is a sign saying a boy died there one year after falling into a crevasse. The hike itself isn't too demanding, lots of elderly and children manage it as it's short (though steep). That being said, you are at an incredibly high altitude and you may find yourself out of breath easier than you expect. My wife struggled as she has an issue with her lungs, but we managed to make it. The glacier itself is impressive and you will get a lot of great photos. I actually found the photos were better from the Icefield Center. You can't see the full scale of it from up close, but it's good for a photo of yourself in front of the glacier. The hike doesn't take too long (30 minutes return) and the parking was fairly empty. I think most people park at the Icefields Center, but there is separate parking nearer the glacier for those walking the trail. It's quite sad seeing all the signs on the drive up saying ""This is where the glacier was in 1985"" and realizing it used to be much, much larger than it currently is."

"How else can one describe the opportunity to stand atop a glacier?True enough, it isn't cheap, but sadly few amazing natural wonders are not exploited in some way or other nowadays. In defence of the exploiters, - they do provide a pretty decent service to and from the glacier in rather specialised and expensive vehicles- it would be almost impossible for the vast majority to access this magnificent natural wonder without them.It was our third visit, spanning 18 years, and yes the glacier is noticeably shrinking even to our untrained eyes. Whether by global warming or other means. They say it may have decades left before it's gone. If you choose to visit, get there EARLY. The gates open at 9.00, be there as early as possible to avoid the hordes who descend from 10.00am onwards.Oh, and wear something that will keep your feet warm and keep you dry if a hail storm blows in. It is a glacier after all. It's astonishing to see the number of short wearing sandal clad numpties stepping out onto the ice and having to immediately retreat back to the Snowcoaches to avoid frostbitten extremities.NB - it's worth booking the glacier skywalk as a combo with the glacier trip. You are shuttled to and from the skywalk after the glacier trip."
"The opportunity to step onto a glacier with such ease was a pretty unique experience and worth the visit. The trip in the truck out onto the glacier was excellent and informative but it is understandably very popular and the area deemed safe to walk on is limited so expect it to be pretty crowded with other tourists.Tips for clothing - as well as general warm clothing - would be something to keep your ears warm and waterproof footwear, as there are slush puddles which you can avoid but would be easier if you don't have to.Also, take an empty bottle as you can drink the melt water, fresh from the glacier!"

"Previous visitors raved about how unique and special an experience this was so my expectations may have been too high. I visited with a bus tour. Our trip was arranged in advance so the whole thing took a total of less than two hours, including a trip to the cafeteria for lunch (big mistake). I understand that for people without pre-paid tickets and for those not coming on tours the wait is considerably longer. This place is very, very touristy. Think several hundred people in the visitor's center/cafeteria area and probably a hundred out on the ice. As part of a tour we got bused up to the drop-off point immediately which was great. The ice explorer vehicles weren't as impressive as I'd been led to believe that they were but the limited experience in them (five minutes) was fun. The driver was an excellent guide. You don't go very far out on the icefield at all, maybe a few hundred feet. Once there the main attraction is to sample the glacier water. The water tastes excellent but if you do this I would be careful to go as far upstream as you can within the boundary limits as there are dozens of other people doing the same thing, putting their hands and bottles into the water. Honestly there are some nice picture opportunities here but not a lot else to do. We spent a grand total of 5 minutes on the ice before returning to the explorer for the five minute journey back to the bus. We were then dropped off to eat at the center. The buffet was just under $30 so we opted for the cafeteria. Mistake. The cafeteria is extremely overcrowded, pricey (I spent $15 on two pieces of pizza) and the food quality was awful. My pizza was dry and unappetizing. It looked like it had spent several hours under a heat lamp. The prices for everything are high including the ice explorer itself. It's a bit of a cash grab.The sheer number of people visiting made this experience a whole lot less appealing to me. It's hard to appreciate the beauty and wonder of this place while jockying for position with hundreds of other visitors. We didn't get a chance to do the Skywalk, which looks intriguing, but our bus driver said that it's actually really poorly placed so we weren't missing much. I'm thinking that this is probably a better experience if you go in the morning to beat the crowd and if you pack your own food."

"I did not have high expectations of the glacier experience, but it was actually AMAZING. Before I get into the details, know that you must book your time IN PERSON. (Probably not an issue in June, but you definitely need to pre-book in July.) We bought our ""Ultimate Explorer"" tickets at the Sulphur Mountain Gondola in Banff, and they did not tell me that I needed to visit a Brewster desk to book the time. You cannot book a time over the phone. I didn't find out until I called the afternoon before and was told I needed to travel all the way to the Lake Louise Chateau to set up a time. It was annoying, but it wouldn't have been so bad if I'd only known ahead of time.An important tip: BRING WARM CLOTHES. It was warm the day we went, but I put on my ear muffs, jacket, and gloves on the glacier. It was COLD out there. There were people in our group in flip-flops, and they must have been freezing. Also, be sure to wear decent shoes. It's ice, so it's slippery.Another tip: Bring an empty water bottle so you can fill it up and drink some glacier water. The skywalk is very fun, but it wasn't as impressive as I expected. I would have been happy with just the glacier experience. (But we did buy the ""Ultimate Explorer"" ticket, so it was included in that.)Last tip: If you're doing the glacier experience and the skywalk, allow three hours from boarding time until arrival back at the centre.Overall, it's worth the experience. "The Ice Highway itself is a sight to behold....stop often and enjoy. After flying from Victoria, BC, to Calgary, Alberta, my wife and I drove six hours to our rental unit in Jasper, Alberta. And what a ride it was, especially along the ice highway between Banff and Jasper National Parks. We were astounded by the kaleidoscopic variations of the mountain wilderness, at times gorgeous, at times savage, and at times surreal.Massive mounds of beveled slate boulders connected to spiraling mountain tops graciously swaddled in snow. Some bare mountain bases looked like ivory carvings; others were pocked-marked with scraggly fir trees. Many of the peaks grotesquely jutted out (like wild primordial warriors) and resembled huge bulky swollen necks thrust over the underbelly of the mountain. Sections of other promontories seem to be caved in, battered and blackened by erosion. After seeing haphazardly strewn boulders beside the highway shoulder, my wife and I knew why there were frequent signs warning of avalanches."

"I last visited the ice field in 1970, when it extended at least a mile or more beyond its current edge and was sturdy enough to support snowcat vehicles full of tourists, long since replaced by buses with ""monster truck"" type tires and a far more limited range.There are signs along the trail pointing out the furthest extension of the ice, by year. It was, frankly, a great disappointment to see how much has been lost due to decades of warming climate, and I fear that, like Glacier National Park in the US (where all glaciers are likely to have melted by 2030), these glaciers will disappear as well and we will all be the poorer for it.All that said, it is worth a stop to experience what remains. The trail is steep in places, and it's rocky enough to make sturdy shoes with ankle support desirable (although you can make it in sneakers if you're careful about choosing your way). Public access is somewhat limited, so if you want to hike deeper into the ice field, it will be necessary to book a guided tour, something we did not have the time or foresight to do but you may wish to give it a try. There's a booth where I think you can book a guided tour right near the trail head, although that may require a wait, and there may be another one at the Discovery Center nearby.Without a guide, a requirement for deeper exploration due to the fragility of the remaining ice, you'll still be able to learn some useful information by reading the signs posted along the way. They'll help you understand the natural processes at work here and also clue you in as to the plants and animals who still make their homes here.I assume that a visit to the the Columbia Ice Field's Discovery Center would be an even better aid to understanding, but it was so crowded we couldn't find a parking space. Moreover, to me, the most important thing is to SEE and to EXPERIENCE directly this unique, vanishing landscape. I especially enjoyed observing all the flat black rocks with vertical scratches made by the glacier, probably as it retreated. It is awesome to imagine the immense forces at play here, and it gives one increased respect for Mother Nature. I wanted to run my fingers through the grooves to touch, literally, the power of the retreating glacier and imagine it as I saw it in what now seem like ""glory days"" 46 years ago.The bottom line: the ice fields will not be here forever, so be sure to see them now, and take your children and grandchildren too, if you have any and can give them such a marvelous adventure."

This was on my bucket list to see a Galcier but I saw loads and the walk up to the toe of one of the glaciers at the ice fields centre is amazing well worth a visit.
"For $80 per person, you can walk on a glacier and do the skywalk as well or for $153 it will include Banff gondola ride and either cruise Lake Minnewanka (Banff) or Lake Maligne (Jasper). We chose the all inclusive $153 package. Icefield discovery centre is where you can buy your tickets and where you board the bus that takes you across the road to join up with the all terrain ice vehicle. The driver of the ice truck will give interesting commentary for the short drive up to the glacier where you hop out and walk on the glacier, fill your water bottles with the purest of water. You only get about 20 minutes on the glacier before you have to return to the ice truck. The ice truck will take you back to the bus that will transport you just down the road to the glacier skywalk (separate review). All in all, a good experience. If you don't want to spend the money, you can see the glacier from the discovery centre and you can go across the road and although it's a bit of a hike up to it, you can walk on the glacier without paying the price. The skywalk you can not get to without paying."
"An experience so stupendous that I am having difficulty stringing words together, even now...a month later!You must go here and see the majesty of the mountains and witness the strengths of glacial waters to carve the landscape. The glacier itself is small and getting smaller as we speak, but is still huge and the ridges of rocks it has left in it's wake as it has progressed and receded over the years easily demonstrates the power of iceflows.We took the bus service and walked on the glacier with a couple of hundred other people. Rewarding in it's own way, but we will walk with a guide on our next visit and brave the crevasses rather than risk damaging the glacier any further.This sounds mean; a little too much like it was alright for me to do it, but you shouldn't because you will damage it, however it is true to say that I will walk lighter next time and hopefully leave the glacier to last longer for others to enjoy"
"So - you need to go with the flow (the 'ice-flow' - bad joke from husband!) You will rarely get a chance to stand on 10,000+ years of history just be prepared to stand on it with 10,000 other people (well more like 200) That said, this operation is slick, enthusiastic and informative as well as being good fun. The inclusive Skywalk is not for the faint-hearted or those with vertigo but is a well delivered experience. The staff residences which are well hidden behind moraine house around 150 staff in high season - and this should tell you how commercial this is and also how well run: Young personable staff make this work."

"We were advised to visit the Columbia Icefields by our travel agent and she was right on the money. We did this between staying at the Fairmont at Jasper and the Fairmont at Lake Louise. The Brewster coach picked us up and our driver Dave and host Danni couldn't have been more helpful. We were a small group which suited is well and we were soon travelling toward the Icefields. However we were lucky enough to stop and see two bears on the roadside at two different locations - first a young Grizzly and second a black bear. We then visited the Athabascar falls ( see separate review) and then onto the Icefields. The tea house wasn't much ( separate review) and we then were driven up to a staging point where we boarded the snow mobile and were slowly and expertly taken up onto the glacier by the driver Tall Mike. It was a surreal experience - we felt like we were on the moon! We got out and had a walk around and filled out water bottles with the freezing 20,000 year old water - so pure. After about 30 minutes we made our way back to the staging area in the snow mobile. Utterly memorable and once in a lifetime. Big thanks also to Dave and Danni for the expert and interesting commentary all the way and to Lake Louise. A great day and a must if you are in this area"

"Our visit to the Athabasca glacier was part of a well organised day tour which also took in the Athabasca falls which originates from the glacier. The trip onto the glacier was all very well organize, coach from the visitors centre to a drop off point at the foot of the glacier and then transfer onto the glacier via a very large snowbus. The driver was informative and amusing telling us that whenever anyone but her drove the bus it had a tenancy to break down (very reassuring especially when descending a very steep slope). Once out of the bus and walking on the glacier its a wonderful sight to take in, camera is a must and if you go prepared with an empty water container you can safely collect and drink the crystal clear glacier melt water. Also recommend good shoes and warm lightweight clothing."

"Amazing place, 5 glaciers in immediate view and words don't do it justice but I recommend getting up close to the glaciers. I was travelling with 3 generations so taking the Brewsters bus tour suited us rather than the Ice Cube walk which looks really good too. This is my 3rd visit and 2nd with the bus tour. Fairly pricey and crowded but the staff are efficient and enthusiastic about the experience making it feel less like being a processed pea. Previously I have visited at quieter times (I would recommend early or later tours avoiding peak time between 11- 4pm paritcularly in high season). I would not recommend staying at the Inn or eating at the eateries at the centre. The latter are extremely poor quality and overpriced. It is sobering to see how the glacier has retreated since my first visits in 1997 and 1999. Take warm clothing and shoes with a good grip for the glacier and don't forget the camera. On the bus tour there is plenty of time allowed on the glacier to take photos, gather ice melt water etc. We also went on the sky walk but the lack of rest rooms after almost 3 hours meant we had to cut it short. Also with the numbers of other visitors around there was no sense of the exposure on the glass-floored balcony. Again pick your time.If money is limited you can walk up the toe of the glacier (but not onto the actual glacier itself unless you have appopriate knowledge, experience and equipment). There is car parking at the visitor centre or down closer to the toe."
