"My husband & I took the package tour through Brewster. Arrive early or book a time ahead to avoid the wait. The centre has a cafeteria, short movie, national park information, and a gift shop - so plenty to keep you busy while you wait.You board a large tour bus that takes you across to the icefield, where you then change bus to the AWD explorer that takes you a short and steep drive (10 mins) on to the glacier. You have about 25 mins on the glacier itself - within a roped off area. It truly is a spectacular feeling and sight. So take it all in and enjoy the beauty!Tips:- bring a jacket, hat and gloves for the glacier- wear shoes with a thick sole and grip (or ice cleats); it is treacherous- don't forget to #sharethechair- AAA, CAA, AMA offer discounts but you have to be on a tour before 11am or after 2 (or3?) pm- to get the discount you cannot book a time ahead; you have to show up- if you buy the Brewster tour package you cannot do the icefield alone without the Skywalk"
"We had a perfect day for the Glacier Adventure and I'd recommend it to anyone if you've never been on a glacier. So we had to sit there for a longer-than-stated-by-the-driver back and forth. Brewster is doing a disservice to their patrons that are only interested in the Glacier. This was not mentioned at all when I booked our trip. I think that is because Brewster has combined the two activities and you can no longer book just the glacier-only Glacier Adventure. What the website did mention was that you could spend all the time you want before boarding the vehicle to return. Folks, that applies to the Skywalk, not the Glacier. We only got 20 min on the glacier. I would've enjoyed more (though 20 would seem like plenty if the weather was not as glorious as we had). "This is the must stop on the Icefields Parkway. You now have to purchase the combo ticket with the Skywalk if you want to take the glacier tour. It continues on the glacier to a large area that was cleared in the middle where the buses park and let you get out and walk on the glacier. You then are brought back to the glacier bus station where you board a regular bus that takes you to the skywalk which is a few miles north of the visitor center. "During our extensive travels, the most beautiful drive we have ever been on is The Ice Field Parkway. This parkway is an extension of the road which traverses Banff National Park and Jasper National Park, two gems of the Canadian park system. Located on the border or Alberta and British Columbia, running north-south, the drive through the spine of the Canadian Rockies is absolutely breathtaking at every turn. Near the halfway point between the cities of Banff and Jasper is the Columbia Ice Field. A very nice Visitor Center is directly across the parkway. Free info on the history of the region and various programs for cost are available at the center. You can walk on the glacier one of two ways. You can pay for the tour, which buses you to the Columbia Glacier, or you can park and walk uphill all the way about 1/2 mile to the glacial face for free. Your choice. If, for any reason, you are in Calgary, a trip through Banff and Jasper National Parks is an absolute must. A stop at the Columbia Ice Field is also a must. This area is beauty at its most primal!"

"They expect the glaciers in the Columbia Ice Field to be completely melted in 100 years -- so see it now while you can. There is actually a marker in the parking lot that shows where the glacier was located in the 1800's and it is amazing how much it has shrunk and retracted. The ride out to the glacier is very informative and fun in huge diesel-powered ice explorer buses. Once out there you can walk on the glacier (in designated areas) and even fill your water bottle from flowing melted glacier water (cold and refreshing). The ticket price includes transportation and admission to the glass-floored skywalk which hangs out over the canyon -- not as frightening as it sounds, but some tourists did freak out and could not go all the way around the walkway. Oh, and for those people who think they'll save some money and just stop at the skywalk as they travel up to Jasper -- gated access for tours only. Hoser! It was a well-spent three hours on a bright sunny day. I am glad we stopped on our way driving up to Jasper, because the original plan was to stop on our way back from Jasper and the weather that day was not as nice."

"This attraction offers a good view of the Columbia Ice Field that feeds several glaciers, of which the Athabasca Glacier is one. Mammoth Brewster Ice Explorers cart passengers across the highway and up to the Athabasca Glacier, where one can get out and walk on the ice and take photos of the glacier, ice cap, and Dome Mountain. The ride up and back takes about 90 minutes. Some visitors have opted to walk up, but beware - there is a wide and deep intentional ""puddle"" that washes off road dirt from the tires of the special glacier buses; it is unwise to try to wade through this frigid water. Dress appropriately for the chilly wind and ice - warm coats and sturdy shoes."

"Columbia Ice Field is actually an extensive glacier system that extends into several glaciers that fall in between mountain ridges. In particular, you are able to access the Athabasca Glacier by either hiking to the foot of it via a short trail or by doing the Brewster Glacier tour to ride an Ice Explorer bus onto the glacier. You can also view Saskatchewan Glacier by hiking atop Parker Ridge Trail. My family did both hikes atop Parker Ridge and to the foot of Athabasca Glacier. Both are different experiences, but worth it if you want to see glaciers without paying a lot to go on a tour. It was really chilly the day we visited Athabasca Glacier, but it was neat to get close enough to it, even though you can tell a lot of it has melted over the years. Highly recommend the hikes if you want to see the glaciers without spending money!"

"This is a case where one must provide context to provide an informative review. I hope I can successfully do that.I can only rate this experience as a full 5 -Excellent because it provides such a unique opportunity for many travelers to experience a part of the natural world that they may never have the chance to do again. Having a major glacier at your fingertips and even to ride/walk out on to it is once in a lifetime for many.But context is important. A simple view from the parking area/visitor building can be stunning if the weather co-operates. I've had the opportunity to pass by about 10 times over the years and only twice has there been a nice clear view. So I hope everyone gets such a day for their visit. There's something about the Icefield, the air flow etc that I have been told the Icefield essentially has its own little micro-climate that ususally involves low hanging clouds. Clear days are to be treasured. On this trip while driving north to Jasper we had a nice partly cloudy day. Since this was the first time my kids were here, I was very happy they could take it all in. I let them know if they wanted to ride out on to the glacier we could do so a few days later on the drive back south. On that day the weather was not as co-operative but their main interest was to ride out and stand on the ice. It's a slow, plodding, time consuming trip but Brewster provides something that again is a unique experience.This is where it gets a little ticklish as I have never thought the excursion out on to the ice, uniqueness aside, was very worthwhile/compelling considering the time and cost. But it still wins those points for the unique experience. I would never discourage anyone from doing it but I think you will see what I mean. I certainly didn't discourage my kids and am glad it was their choice.As I left the choice to my kids, we did not book in advance. I think we visited in the last few hours of the onset of the peak summer rush. There were numerous busloads of tours, but comparatively few casual visitors as I think it was still a little pre-season. Thus I was extremely annoyed that we could not book a trip on to the ice without also being required to pay for the bundled Skywalk visit too without waiting 5 hours. But as long as we paid the extra Skywalk fee we could literally board in minutes to the glacier trip. I can't say anything bad about the Skywalk -- its an interesting structure; however, I also remember stopping by the roadside numerous times right there to observe a great view without needing to pay for it. You can't do that anymore. Something just doesn't seem right about this. But I'll spare the griping.Lastly the modern facilities are seemingly an improvement as this was my first visit in many years. Nice, well maintained facility, including expanded restroom facilities, but it seems mostly a building filled with new ways to get your money. I remember the nostaglic, deteriorating old Icefield Chalet and it's my memory of what a fitting stop here used to be including walking across the road to the glacier approaches. But modern society must move on."
"We had our thoughts about visiting the Athabasca Glacier. It is expensive, specialy as it is offered in combination with the skywalk. Ask for a tickett for just the glacier and forget the skywalk. Try to be there early in the morning or late on the day when it is not crowed. We where with 20 people on the glacier. During the day you can be there with more than 200 people and I can imagine the than the magic is gone!"
"We did the Columbia Ice Field as part of our tour booked with Rocky Mountaineer. We had no idea what it would be like. Good thing we bundled up in Jasper town before we left that morning, cause even though it was end of May, it began snowing furiously before we reached the Center at the base of operations. What a unique experience - taking the ice explorer up to the glacier! Our guide, Stefan, unpacked the significance of our journey (scientifically & naturally -- plus he had a sense of humor that helped!) When we reached the let off point on the glacier, it was snowing so much it was hard to see, but we ventured out & made it up to the Canadian flag (watching the cones, you must do this or risk falling into a crevice!) Truly a highlight of our two-week trip to Canada, plus an incredibly unique experience (since we are unlikely to ever visit Antarctica!) Highly recommend! The center down below offers two cafes - the full service line was too long for us, so we opted for the short (cash only) quickie line of pre-prepared items that actually served hot chicken noodle soup, which helped my brother, who had a cold! A tip - be sure to wear sturdy shoes & warm socks for walking on the glacier, We just had our raincoats & 'layers' but we did fine even in the swirling snow (the center was heated altho the ice explorer itself was a bit cold with everyone opening windows to get pictures!) Fantastic!"

"This is a well run operation. You get bused out to the big ice five,d vehicles which are huge and then trundle uphill and down dale until you reach the glacier - in spite of its title this is not an ice field at all but a glacier. You get out onto the ice and have about 15/20 minutes to look around take photos etc., and then back on the vehicles again. Good fun and we took lots of good photos but beware it is cold and it is slippery as it is currently melting, so do not step in a puddle, you could disappear!"

"At the icefields you can take a guided tour onto the glacier, which can be very cold, or park in the lot at the base of the glacier. From the parking lot you can walk to the toe of the glacier and then up and along a marked path. For your own safety be sure not to go off this path. The walk fro the parking lot to the toe gets longer overhear as the glacier recedes and this is evidenced by the makers that show the position of the toe over time. It is clear that the recession is accelerating. In my lifetime the toe was much closer to the highway."
"For folks from tropical countries it's a rare experience to stand on a glacier even if it's for about 20 minutes and together with hordes of people taking photos or grabbing the ice to make snowballs. Getting there is quite an ordeal with the conveyor belt process of rushing to the washrooms, standing in line for the confusing but rather tasty lunch offerings, spotting the right Brewster bus to take you to another station where you are driven to the snocoach that takes you down and up to the glacier. However both drivers are lively and funny and it's not as cold on the glacier as it is in the bus bays when it is raining and slush threatens your footsteps."

"While for me it was worth every penny of this high-priced ""adventure"" to drink untreated wild glacier melt, I cannot in good conscience recommend others do the same. I'm past my child-bearing years and have lived a good life. Please use your good judgement about drinking untreated water. Having said that, if you have it on your bucket list to stand on a glacier, do it soon. They may not last long. Unless you want to rope up to 4 friends with crampons and ice axes, this is probably a less expensive, much safer way to visit. We went with little kiddos and grannies and had a swell time. Even so, DO wear boots or sturdy shoes and bring rain jacket, hat, sunscreen and water, as you would on any hike. You'll enjoy it much more. (The lady in the strappy shoes definitely did not get as much for her money as the rest of us.) Surprisingly, the best part turned out to be the Skywalk. It looked goofy, but turned out to be more awesome than I thought. If you don't want to stand on glass and look down at 900 feet of air between your feet and the bottom, you don't have to. The view is fabulous anywhere along, and there are tons of nature exhibits with great educational info all along the walkway leading up to the glass. Get the free audio tour. It's okay. And go ahead and look down. It's okay. You know you want to. Just do it."

We always enjoy the glacier tour and (to our surprise) also enjoyed the sky walk. Expensive but worth the splurge.

"Rode regular tour bus to staging area part way up alongside the glacier on gravel road then transferred to glacier capable bus, can handle about 40 passengers, with HUGE tires. It went down a very steep grade of about 35% to the glacier. We stopped on the glacier and walked in a protective area. The tour operator has plowed a large snow wall from the glacier surface to keep the curious from walking on the glacier in potentially an unsafe area even though they are reminded to stay in the protective area. One can see where the glacier has a steep descent from the Columbia Ice Field there are many HUGE crevasses. As many as 5 glacier busses were in the safe area at the same time. We saw a stream of clear water flowing on the glacier due to melting. The snow wall is high so it is hard to see over it, some areas are low enough that one can see the crevasses further up the glacier at a distance of perhaps 0.5 mile."

"Basically a genned up tourist stop by Brewster to fill a need by the tour companies to have a midday stop for lunch for their guests. You got hordes of buses going both directions (North/South) filled with Japanese, Korean and British tourists needing a place to have lunch and stretch the legs a bit. Brewster saw the need and filled it. Kudos to them, so they built this humongous ""Columbia Icefield Discovery Center"" with lots of indoor space to get out of the weather, 2-3 places to eat and a small theater. Quite impressive really and the deck has a nice view of the glacier and surrounding mountains. If you just stopped here and had lunch, got you photo's and maybe checked out the theater for the 30 minute or so film that would be enough, but if you're with a tour group you are going to packaged and processed onto a big shuttle bus, taken up to the transfer station and then get off and then back on the big Ice Explorer for you trip to the glacier. After a 15 minute ride you get to the glacier, basically the turnaround point for the Ice Explorers, and then informed you have 20 mins to explore the parking lot. You're on the glacier at this point, but you're not allowed to exit the turnaround area and go out because it is too dangerous. Then back on the Ice Explorer to the transfer point, off/on to the shuttle bus and then you are forced to go to the Skywalk. You have to purchase both tickets, I'm sure this is for efficiency more than anything as it allows the shuttles to stay in a loop and not have two distinct hubs, one for the glacier and one for the Skywalk. It is not for me to say what anyone person would get from the glacier experience, during good weather maybe you get a terrific view of the glacier and the driver/guides do a good job of relaying timely information about the plants and terrain that you are passing. The view from the Skywalk was not very good, at least when I was there in May, but the engineering of the Skywalk itself is quite impressive."
"lovely to visit the receding glacier. was once covered by forest (so much for man-made global warming) and then the glacial ice encroached. now it's receding again. you'll need to set aside a couple of hours for this at least. they have tied in the new ""skywalk"" tour and have added the cost to the excursion. so be prepared to pay $80 pp. even if you don't do the skywalk. they say that this site may not be here in 70 years so it was definitely worth it."

The ice field from the road is actually quite unattractive. As the ice recedes and we move away from the last ice age the debris of glacial weight us all that is left on the barren field. A remarkable illustration of global warming whether you believe this is a result of mans ignorance and industrial pollutants or the simple cyclic effect of nature over million of years we are definitely getting warmer. Truth is I guess is a combination of the normal warming cycle we are in and have been since the last ice age accelerated by mankind's wilful destruction of our resources (greed) but hey we'll never stop that. Nature will win when's she's had enough and that WILL be a big shout.

This drive on Route 92 between Jasper and Lake Louise is unbelievable. Words or pictures could never do it justice. Wish I would have had time to explore more. There were also Hostels along the trail. Was surprised to see that ski trails were all still open. If you get a chance don't turn it down.
Hiked to the toe of the Athabasca Glacier. We started on the smaller trail to the left but then we climbed and cut across and made it to the edge of he glacier. We made sure not to walk on any of it - as it's dangerous to do so at this time of year. A great hike though and you can observe a number of geologic features. Based on where the terminal moraine is now - you can really tell how much the glacier has receded. There are also lots of striations visible. The are cause when rocks are trapped under the glacier as it advances. The rock gouges into the rock beneath and leaves the striations in the direction of the glacier's advance. A neat hike but a little challenging due to uneven surfaces.
So firstly this is purely a glimpse as you drive up from Lake Louise to Jasper but it is stunning and you seriously don't understand how deep the ice is. If memory serve I think the guide said 100m plus. Well worth stopping for a photo but you have to remember you are in the middle of nowhere and that is something quite special in itself!

"A spectacular spectacle for any to behold. Another one of nature's awe inspiring creations, the glacier Will not disappoint. My beauty wife, myself and our three love creations opted out of the ice bus tour to go for a little self tour like many do. As you drive up toward the glacier parking lot you will notice markers stating the various points at which the freezing giant once sprawled. It's a bit sad to think that one day this majestic ice block will be no longer. But I digress.... Park your vehicle and depending on the time of year, and because you are in the mountains and are about to pay tribute to the ice God's, and ice is cold, bundle up a bit for your brief trek up. The hike will again reveal where the slab once rested at certain periods and it is receding at an alarming rate these days. It may be crowded but not to worry, nature loves all who love her so be patient, what's the rush. I did say that the glacier is shrinking but it will still be there long after your gone. Like most adventures outside, epic or short they are bound to bring anyone to life. When we first arrived our kids weren't to thrilled to have to go for a walk out into the brisk chill of the late Autumn breeze....not to mention we had to pry the younger two from their naps. But, after a few minutes on the trail they turned into little fearless explorers and the world was once again their oyster. Jumping and running and climbing and everything in between I too felt like a kid again because face it, nature's embrace is everyone's happy place! Now as for the glacier itself, there are signs and (meager) barricades to dissuade the public from going onto the ice which is a not a terrible thing. Although the warning is there many a folk still venture out onto the ice, ourselves included. I am in no way saying fit anyone to do this, I am simply stating our experience. Use your own discretion. Respect the glacier and its inherent dangers, nature is nurturing but we all know how deadly she is too.We gingerly climbed up the slippery slope (not very far) keeping the little ones in hand and reveled in the beaming sun coming down on the glistening surface making a great day even brighter. Needles to say, the sights are amazing and the slight risk was worth the experience for us. Safe and happy travels."

"It was a lifetime's experience as out specially designed bus, the Ice Explorer, drove onto the Columbia Ice Field! From the sprawling Visitor Centre, well provided with restaurants, washrooms etc., a normal bus takes you to the stand - about four minutes drive - from where you change over to the Ice Explorer. The journey itself on this special bus is very exciting, as the bus navigates steep gradients to reach the ice field formed by the Athabasca glacier. In both the buses the drivers gave lively commentaries on the history and geography of the region. We were lucky to get a lovely, sunny day and it was an amazing experience walking on the fresh snow. Special snow shoes are not necessary. There is an ice-melt stream running across the glacier which is said to be the fountain of youth. We were handed small paper cups by our guide cum driver to drink the ice-cold, pure water and we all had cups full with the hope it would work for us!"

"This is a spectacular glacier, which is moving surprisingly fast at about 5mm a day!! The bus takes you directly onto the large flat area near the front. Very cold as you might imagine, and the ice is actually blue. This is due to the aeons old compression of the snow to the point where the air has been expelled, and the light is refracted through pure ice."
"This is the largest body of ice in the Rockies, and probably the most commercialized glacier tour. For me, that is a good thing. It’s within view of Icefields Parkway, at Icefield Centre, where out 39-member tour group boarded a bus for a ride to the staging area. There we took a tank-like bus, descended an incredibly steep slope to the edge of the ice field. The trek is designed for the tire-treads to pass through a stream of glacial melt, to wash away debris and prevent dirt from accumulating on the glacier, which would accelerate melting. The informative and humorous glacier-guide provided details about the vastness and movement of the glacier. It’s necessary to obtain tickets at Icefield Centre—at which I understand there was a consider wait in early September—but the tour company had prearranged tickets for the group and our tour guide had phoned ahead with the estimated time of arrival. We waited less than ten minutes to be on our way to the river of ice, something this Floridian is not likely to see anytime soon. To experience this incredible learning adventure, I recommend prearranging for tickets, if possible."

"One of the interesting or maybe more aptly put concerning details about the Glacier is its rate of retreat. Our first visit to the Ice Fields was in 1990, then in 2003 and now Sept 2015. It's quite alarming to see the difference. The markers than indicate where the edge of the glacier was on the specified years gives you a sense of how the retreat of the Glacier has accelerated over the decades i.e. Global Warming. From the parking area to the edge of the glacier is now quite a hike compared to how close you could get in 1990. in 2003 we did the Brewster tour that took you out onto the ice with those huge ballooned tired buses, the road along the glacier has changed a lot since then. The mounds of gravel and rock that has been left from the Glaciers retreat presents a bit of a hike to get over the hill to close in on the actual glacier. I wonder how far back the edge will be in another 25 years?"

What an incredible experience to be walking on a glacier. We were part of a tour so our transport onto the Athabasca Glacier was pre booked which was good as there were hundreds of tourists at the Icefield Chalet and a lot of them were lined up waiting to get tickets. To get on to the glacier you have to get a bus from the chalet across the road and down the mountain road to a shelter where you wait for an 'ice explorer' vehicle to take you onto the glacier. These vehicles are huge with massive tyres. We had friendly informative drivers on each of the transport legs. You need to wear a warm jacket and shoes suitable for walking on wet ice. It is a real treat to be on the glacier. You have time to walk around and enjoy the experience before doing the return trip . We were advised to take a bottle to collect glacial water from the little melted rivulets which we did. The water is wonderfully fresh and tastes great. The ice is an incredible aqua colour in places and looks really amazing. So glad we had the opportunity to experience this as part of our Canadian holiday.
This place is something else. Very cold but a definite visit wont disappoint. We had so much fun here and the bus driver ( Rick ) was so much fun and very helpful.

"I have been to the Columbia Icefield three times during the last 4 years and in three different seasons. It has been accessible in April and October – for sure in July as well. And it has been worth seeing it in all seasons.I am not sure when they start their season for taking the bus up to the glacier, because I never did it. I did not see any reason to do so, because I think you can already get much of the impression of the glacier from the areas, which are easily accessible by parking the car on the parking spot north of the Icefields Parkway and walk a few hundred meters. I am also not willing to support what I by now just call the Brewster Mafia, which run most of the tourism businesses in the park – the tours up the glacier as well. In my opinion it is absolutely ridiculous how many Brewster buses you see in the park and they do have the most impact on noise pollution due to keeping the engine running in idle to keep the inside of the bus nice and comfy for the tourists who try to see 28 highlights of the park in half a day. The only good thing I could possibly say about this, is, that these groups “pollute” the hotspots just for a short time and just in a circle of maximum 500m diameter around the bus. If you think: Man, this is crowded, either wait 15 minutes a walk a little further and off the beaten tracks and you will be alone again.One last word: Should you consider to spend an additional 30 bucks for the Glacier Skywalk, think about it again. The spot, where Brewster has built this “thing” has been a parking space with a nice view until the beginning of this year – and it was for free!!! Now they charge you and the money is directly transferred into the pockets of Brewster – nothing at all stays in the park. In my opinion projects like this should be boycotted.This is the main reason, I rate the Icefield just 4 stars."
"As part of a planned tour of the Rocky Mountain area we spent half a day visiting and travelling to the glacier. The visit begins at a large reception building that also doubles as a bus terminal for tourists in, and glacier vehicles out. It also the terminus for another attraction further down the road called the ""Sky Walk"". This is a suspended glass floored curved walkway that allows breath taking views of a deep gorge. The ice bus is a special vehicle high up on huge wheels and holds about 30 people. They are custom made and there are only twenty three in existence (22 at the glacier and one with the Canadian government). The ride crawls over the moraine field and up the slope of the glacier to a plateau where you disembark for a few minutes on the ice. Tourists are asked to remain near the bus as there are deep fissures in the ice that can be fatal. The glacier is disappearing a few metres each year and is an area of natural beauty. The Canadian park authorities are extremely protective of the environment and it is rumoured that this attraction may lose it's license in the near future. Clearly an amazing one off experience, with little or no physical effort. See it before it disappears off the map."
"Very well organised tour.Though the Restaurant can be busy.Food is nothing special.You are transported to the perimeter by coach, and then onto the impressive Snow Coaches.We had a running commentary by Patruck the driver.We had a blizzard throughout which added to the atmosphere.Altogether a great experience."

"One of our favorite places on the planet. We did the guided glacier walk in 1988. We did the special bus onto the glacier in 1993. While the busloads of tourists at the ice field center is a turn-off, we understand that this is the method most people use to get to this magical place. Book ahead if you want to partake in the commercial services provided. However, know that you can make the free (with park admission) 30-minute hike from the ice field center (10 minutes from a parking lot below the glacier) to a hill overlooking the toe of the glacier and the milky river flowing from it. This lookout location was under ice the last time we were here, documenting for us the glacier's recession. If you can stay after the daytime crowds have departed, you will get to experience the true magic of this place, complete with glacier-generated weather and stunning sunsets. As a place to visit, I would award it with 5 stars; the masses of tourists we encountered at the ice field center this time caused me to lower my score."

"In spite of heavy smoke from forest fires, we thoroughly enjoyed this trip onto the Columbia Icefield. Tall Mike, the driver of the Icefield Explorer, handled the patter beautifully, making every story or joke feel fresh and original (though all guides are trained to say the same things). Other reviewers have made a good suggestion: book ahead. Brewer has the corner on this market. The company's buses offer several tours and offer package deals. But from our perspective, the best reason to book ahead is that you avoid a long queue and potential disappointment. A bus takes you from the Columbia Icefield Centre to the point where you board one of the huge-tired buses that can handle the steep, shifting terrain. From there it is a short ride out onto the icefield. The 20-minute stop there is sufficient to get a sense of the majesty of the icefield and to fill a bottle with glacier melt."

"I highly recommend purchasing tickets as a combo at ""http://www.brewster.ca/canadian-rockies/destinations/banff/activities/explore-rockies-combo-packages/"". According to Patrick, he has been working there for 2 years. I believe, someone should tell him that the Canadian Flag should never touch the ground. Let me explain. Since this was the last tour of the day, Patrick was doing a clean sweep, preparing the area for the next day. He was picking up safety cones and tossing them over the glacier water creek. When visitors were done taking pictures with the Canadian Flag, he yanked it out of the ice and also tossed it along with the safety cones. In my opinion, this is considered a Flag desecration. If you must remove the Flag, take it back to the Columbia Icefield Glacier Discovery Centre, but never let it touch the ground. Be respectful. Thank you for listening."

"The Columbia Ice Field is still beautiful, though the glaciers are rapidly receding. There are beautiful views and magnificent snow-topped mountains wherever you look. Icy blue streams sparkle in the sun along the roadways. Take your time driving this roadway. You don't want to hit any wildlife. We didn't see any on this trip, but maybe they're out there somewhere. I hope so. There are lots of pullouts for great photo opportunities and rest stops are available as well. We first visited this area in 2007 (see my review). It has changed since then. Be careful when you drive the road, especially near the popular sites. People get excited to see these places and don't always think about safety."
Having hiked on and travel to glaciers the Glacier Crawler was the easiest way we have traveled to a glacier. The trip up begins with a short bus ride from the Ice Centre to the Glacier Crawler terminal. There you board the Crawler for a 20 minute slow ride to the glacier field. You see the many layers of rock and glacier formations on the trip up and back from the glacier. You spend about 20 minutes on the glacier itself. If you have never experienced a glacier this is a good way to start but if you have hiked glaciers this will be a little disappointing.

"Such an awesome experience. The trip was approximately one hour with about 20 minutes spent on top of the glacier. Originally I thought 20 minutes was not enough but when we were at the top, it was quite cold. We took pictures FAST!Our drivers had great facts, stories, anecdotes about the glacier for us. They patiently answered all questions fired at them.I have a few recommendations: 1) TICKETS -- We bought our tickets in advance in the Brewster's Banff Office. We planned the particular time and day that we wanted to visit but I'd confirmed that if we missed the time (i.e., couldn't make it somehow), we could go into the offices to re-schedule a time. They have an office in Lake Louise too. 2) DRESS -- Everyone says to dress warmly. Bring lots of layers or warm clothing. You can always take off if you're hot. On the day we'd visited, it was about 7C at the pick up point (Columbia Ice Centre). When we arrived at the top of the glacier, our driver told us it registered about -5C. It was pretty windy that day and the wind could cut through clothing if you're not prepared. 3) Hiking poles for the elderly - If you're elderly, you may want to bring hiking poles to the top. I'd assisted and had at least one elderly person hold my arm to the bus as the surface was icy and slippery at times.We would love to visit again."

"I went on both the Skywalk as well as the Ice field tour about a week ago with a friend. We had arrived just before noon. We had bought a combo deal for both the skywalk and the Ice field. The Discovery center as quite packed as soon as we walked in. We acquired our tickets and headed up to the cafeteria. The cafeteria was absolutely packed and we were very lucky to find a table that was just vacated just as we were looking for one. I think in hindsight it may have been a better experience to eat in the dinning room. The Skywalk consisted of a but trip to the Skywalk, a playback devices that give you information at several points along the walk path to the Skywalk. The patch is paved and walled, very family friendly, wheelchairs and strollers should have no issue. The trip to the glacier however was amazing. The shuttle bus ride taking us to the transfer point to board the Ice Explorer was only a few minutes long. The driver explained a little about the environment on the way to the transfer station. We boarded Ice Explorer #39 with Dakota as the driver. It was an amazing experience. Dakota was informative and engaging on the 15 minute trip to the glacier and the trip back to the transfer station despite likely having repeated the same information countless times. She was quite informed on anything anyone asked, was very easy to speak with and was quite entertaining. She made my first trip to the Ice field better then I expected it would be and I sincerely hope the next time I go back to the Ice field I am able to get back on Dakota's Ice Explorer again.Going to the Skywalk it would be best to bring:Camera, jacket and pants (thin sports pants should suffice) and it can get windyThe shuttle to the Skywalk will take approx 12-20 minutes.This walk can be done at your own pace with shuttles arriving every 15 minutes to return you to the Discovery Centre.*There are no washrooms at the Skywalk*Going to the Ice field it would be best to bring:Camera, jacket and pants as it will likely be windy even in the valley.A bottle or some other container for drinking the glacier water.The shuttle to and from the transfer point should be about 5 minutes.The Ice Explorer ride to the glacier will be about 15 minutes.There is about 15-20 minutes on the glacier.As you will very likely be taking the same Ice Explorer back to the transfer station there should be no issue with leaving some belongings on the bus while on the glacier.The bus I was on is not wheelchair or stroller friendly, however they may have a newer bus that would be more accommodating."

We did an amazing 3 hour ice walk on the glacier last week. We organised this via the tourist information office in Jasper. As we booked ahead we could pick to depart at 1.30pm. He had 40 years experience of guiding and was very knowledgable about the Athabasca Glacier and the ice fields behind the glacier. This was a truly memorable trip. The surroundings are stunning and the walk up to the glacier is thrilling. However the biggest thrill is putting on the basic crampons and the striding out onto the Glacier itself. This is a once in a lifetime experience for many and we loved it. The ice is immense. Streams are running down the surface and there are huge mill wells where water has cut holes into the ice. The guide knows where these are and steers you well clear. (It was still amazing to see people walking out in trainers with no guide completely oblivious to the risks). You walk about 2 km up onto the ice. To my mind this seemed a better deal than the bus tour where you only got 15-20 minutes on a small area of the ice.

"This review is about IceWalks, a company that offers walks up the glacier, on foot, from the toe of the glacier right up onto the heart of the glacier. Make sure you go with www.icewalks.com Just to be clear, we did not do the Brewster’s bus tour. We could have taken a comfortable (costly and cossetted) bus trip onto the glacier for a little while, but my family wanted a longer and more personal encounter with the Athabasca Glacier and that’s exactly what we got, and more. If one is infirm walking on uneven ground, or pushed for time, then maybe a bus trip could be worthwhile, but if you’re fit and have time available, why would you? Walking on the glacier was amazing. Up close and personal, it was an unforgettable experience. The colours, including the browns and greys, as well as the shades of icy-blues and sparkling ice-whites, have to be seen to be believed. We held up a chunk of ice to the sun and it was diamond-clear. The touch and taste (yes, we ate some) of the glacier is memorable as is the sense of one’s smallness amongst the power of the natural processes taking place in and around the glacier. The landscape is awesome. The undulating nature of the glacier surface, hewn mainly by crystal-clear icy water, was impressive – close encounters with deep icy-blue holes, arches, meandering rivulets, waterfalls and cracks were unforgettable. We walked about 2.5km up the 6km glacier, and zig-zagged our way across most of it in our 3hr “Ice Cubed” Walk. We loved the sense of adventure, of being on the ice, in (company provided-) crampons. I wish we had booked the longer Deluxe walk!Our guide Richard was a really nice guy, very knowledgeable (the tour is an interpretative one, not just a walk) and he explained very simply and clearly many of the landforms and natural processes going on around us (Mars Bars will forever taste differently!). He also made sure we were safe (it’s not a risk-free environment) and is an experienced mountaineer.This was one of my top highlights from 2.5 weeks in western Canada. The Company was professional, expert, and customer-focused. The environment was stunning: powerful and beautiful. The experience was informative, eye-opening and unforgettable. www.icewalks.com #HighlyRecommended"

The longest wait will be for the Glacier tour, the Sky walk tour can be done in less than an hour. There is a cafeteria for you to buy slightly expensive food but it's not bad. The bus tour its self starts when you first take a tour bus to the glacier then transfer to the monster wheel buses that take you out onto the ice. The ice here is thicker than the Eiffel tower is tall, also, its about 70% smaller than it used to be when it was first discovered. Lots of good humor and educational moments during the tour, you get about 15 minutes on the glacier to take pictures (i know it doesn't seem like much) but it is pretty chilly and should suffice. There is one thing you need to be aware of even if you buy your tickets and print them out before hand, you need to line up to obtain tickets that have times for when you will be able to attend the attraction. If you have already printed your tickets out online, proceed to the desk beside the gift shop to get your time for the tour. have fun!"

"Just did the short columbia ice field lookout trail. You turn west off the parkway and park at the base of the glacier. from there it is a short 1.5km look with a short rise to the plateau. "I have been to the Columbia Ice Field before as a child, but my husband, Mum-in-Law and daughter had not and I was keen to see it again, so off we went :) We drove along the Icefields Parkway from Jasper, stopping at a few sites along the way. When we arrived we immediately lined up for tickets for the Glacier Adventure where you take the snow-coaches onto the actual Athabasca Glacier, run by Brewster. We made it onto the last tour of the day, at 6:15pm. It is extremely well run and efficient how they call you 10 min before your departure time, your tickets are scanned, then you wait in line just a short time, less than 10 minutes, to board the transfer bus which will take you up to the staging area below the glacier. It was quite cold and windy at the staging area, but that is to be expected at such a high elevation, even in August. The transfer to the snow-coach was quick as well. Both drivers were informative, but our snow-coach driver, a young French-Canadian woman was hilarious! She did a wonderful job of giving us lots of information, but lots of jokes too. Once you are up on the glacier you are given 15 minutes to walk around, explore within the safe area and you can even drink the fresh glacial melt water straight off the glacier! Everyone was very professional and friendly, I would highly recommend this experience to anyone. It is completely worth the money (which you save 25% off of the price by showing your CAA or AMA or AAA card)!"

This is a popular activity so you need to book in advance. You meet at the restaurant and are taken down to near the glacier by their bus. From here you transfer to one of their purpose-built vehicles to go to the glacier. Each vehicle costs over a million dollars and the tyres are $5000 each. The drive to the glacier is short but exciting as you travel along the world's steepest road. On the way there you go down this perilous slope hoping that the brakes/engine can stop you from tumbling head over heels on to the ice. On the way back it is a steep climb up. The guides on both the bus and the vehicle give you an interesting commentary about glaciers and the flora and fauna. Surprisingly many of the drivers are young women - but don't let that put you off! You get to spend about 15 minutes on the glacier itself and that is a unique experience. Make a note of the number of your vehicle so that you don't get left behind. Also dress warmly as the wind can be pretty bitter up there. Overall a really magic experience.

"This is a heavily visited natural site, and very unlike other Alberta attractions. The glacier is a small part of the Field, and Park Rangers can offer more important information than all the publicity for the bus visits and the Skywalk."
"I was really excited about stopping at Athabasca Glacier and the Columbia Ice Field.....my husband, not so much but even he was won over in the end. You can park across the street from the Columbia Ice Field center and access a path that will take you to the edge of the glacier. The path is not very long but it is uphill all the way so it is not handicapped-accessible or for anyone who's out of shape. You can not walk on the glacier due to the danger of falling into a crevasse but there is no charge and the overwhelming beauty and starkness of seeing the glacier up close is well worth the effort. As you walk up to the glacier, various points are marked that show you where the glacier used to be and how much it's receded over the last century. Remarkable to see how much has been lost but glorious to see a piece of nature still so awe-inspiring. That being said, the ice field center is an absolutely madhouse. The tangle of cars in the parking lot, the sheer number of visitors tripping over each other as they register and sign up for the tours in the glacier vehicles would be enough to send many people over the edge, no pun intended. (I only know because I entered to find washrooms. I was successful but later discovered that facilities are also available at the bottom of the path.) There is a large gift shop in the center but you would need a crowbar to pry apart the crowd of tourists. My strong suggestion is to stay outside, avoid the long lines, high fees and use your own two feet to see this phenomenal force of nature."

You access the glacier on an all-terrain Ice Explorer (they are amazing) and then once you are up on the glacier, you can get out and explore a little. The glacier is beautiful and access is restricted to a specific area - for obvious reasons - but you can wander around enough to get away from the crowd to get some lovely photos, and if you have an empty drinking bottle, I highly recommend filling it with the running glacier water. I saw the Columbia Ice Field and the Athabaskan Glacier in 1972. A photograph I took then shows the extent of the glacier down the valley floor. Since then the glacier has retreated considerably up the valley. It's clear that the glaciers are retreating (for whatever reason) and experiencing these majestic structures is a profound experience for anyone who loves exploring our world. Taking the tour on the glacier is worth it. One tip is to stay at the Glacial View Inn and take the first tour in the morning. It's less crowded.

It is sad to see that the top of the ice sheets are barely white due to pollution but the driver who was also giving the commentary was really good and well informed maintained that compared to the other effects of global warming the running of the buses over the glacier did not create any great harm. Where else can you ride around in a million dollar bus with huge tires. The children on the tour really seemed to enjoy it as much as the adults. There is a trail up past the visitor center by the car park. It has a plaque that has where the end of the glacier was in the 1800s. Amazing how much it has receded in a relatively short amount of time. Do not miss this sight. Worth the drive, money etc."

"We took the tour of the sky walk overlooking the canyon at the Ice Fields in Jasper National Park with our 3 grandkids aged 5, 8 & 11. The middle one resisted going because she thought it would be boring but seemed to enjoy it pretty much. The plexi-glass floor and railing takes some getting used to, but the most nerve racking part of the experience was actually the steel gtaing walkway coming off the sky walk. That and the group of tourists that couldn't resist jumping on the floor in the middle of the skywalk. They did apologize, so we didn't throw them over the side.I recommend you try your best to get to the bus departure area and buy your tickets (CAA discount, by the way) as early as possible as later in the day the skywalk can get so crowded you can barely move of see the floor. Tickets are also cheaper before 11 AM. I did it once for the grandkids experience and I won't do it again because I fundimentally disagree with replacing a public parking and viewing area with a for-profit private enterprise geared toward private bus access in a National Park."

For more money than I care to remember we visited the monopolistic Brewster run Colombia Ice Fields. Brewster runs a taught ship and expects you to pay for it. After eating a tres expensive meal we arrived at our bus at an appointed time. This allowed us to be transported to the ice field where one of 23 million plus vehicles transported us to the part of the ice field they certified as safe. Which means they plowed it and packed it down or roped off the crevices. They let you walk around the ice field for about twenty minutes and bus you back to home base. The main attractions are sipping melting ice water and looking at the pretty scenery.And Brewster employs many people.

"We walked on a glacier in Alberta, Canada. The 6 wheel drive vehicle driven by an Australian lass was as much a treat as the walk and visual of the cut away prepared for the tourists. We left Jasper early and arrived shortly after 0900 – there was hardly anyone around and we got on a 0930 coach out to the glacier – there were only 7 of us! When we got to the glacier we were the only tundra buggy out there for the entire 20 or so minutes! We had the place to ourselves – wonderful. On the way to the glacier it was tipping it down with rain but just as we got our tickets the sun came out and it was glorious (although still cold on the glacier) - the view and the experience was amazing. We took an empty water bottle (as recommended on TA) and filled it with pure glacier water which we were advised is perfectly safe to drink – you can’t get any purer than getting water from the glacier yourself! By the time we got back the visitors centre was packed. Enjoyed a very nice (but very expensive) hot chocolate - it was the most expensive hot chocolate we had on our trip of the Rockies. I had visited 15 years ago – so sad to think that it has retreated about 150 meters during that time – so if you get the opportunity – see it now!

We boarded the bus that took us out to the pick up point for the ice explore for the short but interesting ride to the glacier itself, our driver Dave was informative with a great sense of humour. Standing there was just so unbelievable, snow and ice everywhere something that will remain with us forever. You are only permitted to stay on the glacier for 30mins but in that time you know your in a very special place, we took some fabulous photos that we look back on in awe and realise just how lucky we were to visit such a wonderful place so far away from home."

The Icefields Parkway in Alberta Canada follows the continental divide from about Lake Louise to Jasper. Along this spectacular drive is the Columbia Icefields. At the Icefield visitors center you can take an excursion onto the glacier in a huge vehicle designed for glacier travel. It also allows guests the opportunity to walk on the glacier. This journey includes some of the most spectacular views of the Canadian Rockies World Heritage sites.

I even had the chance to collect some really pure glacier water that comprised natural run-off, and am looking forward to making ice cubes from it to have with some decent scotch in the near future!"

"The tour itself is interesting and the view is second-to-none. It's amazing to stand on a thousands-years old glacier (it's apparently is as deep as the Eiffel Tower is tall) in the middle of beautiful craggy mountains. The trip up to the glacier in the snow coach is also fun. However, I'm torn as to whether the $57 price tag is worth it. If you've never had the opportunity to do this before, then probably. As for the visitor's centre, you have to go there to buy your tour ticket, but otherwise, I'd give the place a skip. Parts are under renovation so maybe it's being spruced up a bit, but overall the facility is pretty Plain Jane, with an over-priced tacky tourist shop and a ridiculously over-priced, non-inviting cafeteria that serves uninspired fried food. The bathrooms weren't overly clean either. Overall, I'd say tour the glacier, but don't spend any more money at the visitors' facility."

"Have driven the icefields parkway quite a few times, both in summer and winter. If you ever get the pleasure of driving this deserted stretch of highway in the winter, you'll realize why it's called the ""icefields parkway"". Road is pretty much a skating rink between nov-march. On one particular snowy winter drive through the night from Jasper to Lake Louise, I had to swerve way off onto the shoulder to avoid an obstacle course of car sized snow drifts that formed on the highway from the winds blowing down across the Columbia Ice Field. Such an amazing area that truly makes you realize both mother nature's beauty and power!Bring snow tires and a camera :)"
"We made a planned stop here whilst driving from Banff to Jasper, After buying the Ultimate explorer ticket from Brewsters in Banff, which gave us access to this and 3 other attractions, including the Glacier Skywalk. This ticket is more cost effective than paying for each attraction separately.It is recommended you queue up as soon as you arrive at the visitor centre and get your timed ticket for the tour bus as we had been advised queue lines can get quite long, although we only had to wait for 20 minutes for our tour time.Very well organised. A bus takes you to the foot of the Glacier where you transfer to the Ice Explorer bus which drives onto the glacier. Drivers are knowledgeable and give humorous commentary. We had about 15 minutes on the ice, which is plenty of time to look around, take photos etc.Hint: Take an empty water bottle each with you and have a go at filling it up with fresh running glacier water....probably the best water in the world !!!.You also get the bus from the visitor centre to the skywalk (there is no public parking at the skywalk so this is your only option) This ticket is not timed and you can spend as long as you want at the skywalk."

At the end of the road a parking lot lets you get out and hike across glacier-marked rocks."

"This is a perfect spot to stop and think about ice ages and what glaciers can do to a landscape. The Athabasca Glacier drops down from the Columbia ice field that sits on the mountains tops and the road comes quite close. The glacier tongue has been retreating for decades so the landscape that was covered only 1-4 generations ago by ice is now exposed and you can see how fast the plants move into the new habitats. Quite remarkable how nature claims back anything that is not covered by ice. Also, check out the beautifully polished rock surfaces (bedrock) or the polished cobbles or small boulders. The walk from the lower parking lot up to the ridge takes about 20 min. Dress warm as a cold wind blows always down the glacier. We did not bother taking the bus up onto the glacier ice as the wait and line-up was quite long and we have been on glaciers many times before. If this is your first and only experience, it may be a very good and convenient way to visit up-close the Athabasca Glacier. If you have a full day - a must do is the hike up to Wilcox Pass. If the weather is great - this gives you a stunning view over the ice field and the Athabasca and Dome glaciers. The start is from the Wilcox Day use area a bit down the road towards Lake Louise. You don't need to go all the way up even 1 hrs up the trail it is an absolutely rewarding view."

"We visited the Ice fields when we were kids, and we have been returning about every 10,15 years. We were simply amazed at the changes to the Ice Field and to the surrounding area. You can walk or drive down to the valley floor (free) and then hike up and then down close to the Ice field (free) The hike up is steep , no handicap access on this portion. You can take the snow cats ($$). Well worth the climb or the snow cat. Read the signs, they will tell you were the snow was and when."

"There are good guides on the special bus (Brewster Ice explorer) that takes you to the middle of the glacier. The 90 minute trip costs approx. $50ea and was worth doing. The ice mass is one of the largest south of the artic. The glaciers are receding every year. 70% of the world’s water comes from glaciers. The streams from this glacier flow to three oceans, Pacific, Atlantic and Artic. Very cold out there, dress appropriately and go early to avoid the queues"

"I think the thousands of people do this experience every week. So, this is not a private experience. You do, however, get to walk for a few minutes on an actual glacier. Also it's not cheap. I think we paid 40-50$ per adult. The big ice buses they use to take people up to the glacier are interesting. The wheels are 8-10 feet tall. Also, on the way up you will at times be traveling at a 45 degree angle. The actual experience walking on the glacier was difficult to fully appreciate. The area they allow you to walk on is rather boring. Actually it reminded me of walking on a frozen lake. They have to restrict the area people walk in due to the extreme hazards that are possible on a glacier. People have actually died trying to walk on these glaciers by themselves. I should mention that it's possible to do an actual ""walk up"" the glacier with an experienced guide. I think this hike (with the guide) can be arranged at the visitor center.I should mention the Ice Field Visitor center has an ok/fine restaurant. We made the mistake of stopping at the awful Saskatchewan Crossing place on the way up from Lake Louise. Also, I think the skywalk portion of the Ice Field experience was a big rip-off"

"Anyone can experience the ice field even if without technical skills or ice climbing equipment. 2 options are available: car+easy walk to the front of the glacier (for free), or bus tour directly on the ice field (c.a. 50 CAD per person). The tour brings you on the biggest glacier of the Rockies, where you can walk and even feel like an expert mountaineer. The drive to the glacier itself is super fun aboard those big monster-buses and the crew is friendly and puts you at ease. ( if you are sitting in the front rows they might even let you switch the gear!) Be careful: it's a glacier, it's cold in all seasons. Definitely worth the price."
The Columbia Ice Field is the only freely accessible glacier in North America except those in Alaska. You can take a short hike to the glacier or ride on the glacier via the Glacier Adventure offered within the park for a fee.

"Spectacular scenery and a large visitor centre with plenty of parking and washrooms. The glacier itself can be reached by either walking up a trail to the face, or by shuttle bus which leaves from the visitor centre and takes you up and onto the centre of the icefield, where you can step outside onto the ice for a photo. These shuttle leave about every 15 minutes. There's a great place, a short drive away, called ""The Crossing"" if you don't want to eat at the iceflields centre or it's too crowded in the busy season. The Crossing is a restaurant and cafe, so it's your choice whether you have time for a longer meal or just want a quick snack in the cafe. Great food (try the Yam Fries in the cafe). Good prices and the staff were met were helpful and polite."

"Before arriving we had researched the tourist trappings and decided against it. The Visitor Centre holds very little information but is a good comfort break. The combined ticket of bus and Skywalk seemed a complete rip-off to me (particularly the Skywalk is 6 kms away and basically gives views that you can get by pulling to the side of the road and peering over the edge). That being said if you want the experience of walking actually on the Glacier then this is the only way you can do it. We drove and parked about half a kilometer from the Glacier and took a stroll up the hill to the edge. It was a beautiful sunny day with azure skies and the photos do not indicate how blooming cold it was (why am I surprised - I was stood on the edge of an icefield) so take a coat even if it is warm in the car park. The information boards along the walk were informative and fences kept you away from the dangerous areas (apparently Glaciers have a healthy appetite for unsuspecting children!)Now this is personal so take it or leave it - don't bother parking on visitor center car park but drive to the car park directly underneath the Glacier (if open) and take the walk uphill to the edge. Take whatever photos you want and then get right back to the car. For me the surrounding mountains are more spectacular than the Glacier, especially if they have snow on them and the view from the road at the top of the hill gives you a full panorama. There were road works around the Skywalk when we passed it and although they are trying to make it something exceptional we saw better views from big bend and pull in places all along the Icefield Highway."
"Being from Calgary, Jasper is right in my backyard, so I figured I would take advantage of it! Booked the tickets online for the Columbia Ice Fields and the Skywalk - and it was an amazing experience! First off the day was gorgeous, the sun was shining and the sky was blue. Getting to the Information Centre was extremely easy, lots of parking. I do suggest getting there early before the tour buses. A coach bus took us up closer to the glacier, where we then transferred to 1 of 23 (in the world!) - 6 wheeled vehicles designed specifically for this! Our guide on this vehicle (Shane) was extremely knowledgeable, funny and really enjoyed what he did... And it showed. Jokes about smurfs drinking gatorade to turn the glaciers blue, to very informative information about 700 year old trees... It was the perfect mix of fun and facts. Once on the glacier it was an experience and a half to walk on 600 feet of ice... How many years did it take for that moment! P.S. Do NOT forget to bring a water bottle and fill up with THE freshest water you'll ever taste... Straight from the source! Back down to the centre a bus was waiting to take us to the Glacier Skywalk. Open May 2014, there were audio guides to use (free with admission) with info on the ecosystems, glaciers, history, and many stops along the way for the photo lovers out there - and being able to go at your own pace and not be herded along in a tour was so great. The glass bottom loop at the end taking you out above the canyon was great, perhaps a little overrated, but the exhibit as a whole was wonderful. Definitely worth the day trip. The staff were fantastic with jokes and smiles, answering any questions anyone had. Everything was set up very well, and we didn't have to queue for very long for anything. As well, make a day of it and do one or two of the hikes around the area and check out some of the lakes and beauty of the area... Need at LEAST a day if not two for this area alone!"

The Ice Explorer driver was very informative in pointing out many geologic formations and explaining how the glacier is quickly receding each year. One can also hike from a parking lot near the glacier and walk out onto the glacier, but the Ice Explorer takes you much farther out onto the glacier than you can walk (unless you have the proper boots and protective gear.) "When considering atmospheric warming and the shrinking of ice fields and glaciers in the Northern Hemisphere this is a graphic example with suitable signposting and notices on what's left of the glacier (still quite a lot but nothing like there was 100 years ago) showing the points lower down the mountainside the ice reached in previous years. There are also icefield tours in some kind of bus as well as guided hikes across the ice. These are unlikely to be helping the situation greatly.This is a much visited attraction with its own tourist centre on the other side of the highway with associated catering and masses of bus tours calling in.All said, the glacier and surrounds are still spectacular but nothing like their undoubted appearance from decades gone by."

You can get the same views for free along the numerous pullout along this highway. Many a lot more spectacular than this Skywalk. Also note - if you have disability or mobility issues, there is a rather lengthy walk to get to the Skywalk, with no benches so that you can rest.This attraction is a real ripoff."

"Stopped on way between Banff and Jasper. We arrived around 11am so the queues were small and we booked our Glacier tour for 12.30. By lunchtime the queues were very long. We had lunch in the cafe. Pre-made sandwiches and rather expensive but you are long way from the nearest town here!We booked the Glacier and Skywalk. You are given a time for the Glacier but can do the Skywalk at any time. The clerk booking our Glacier told us we were on the 12.30. Our tickets said 12.15 so be warned - check your ticket! as otherwise you might miss your slot.Just to stand on the glacier was a very neat experience. It is a bit slippery and you can't see the puddles so waterproof footwear is a good idea but people were wearing all sorts! It was a very hot day, but it is still cool on the glacier so take layers. You are only outside for about 15 mins. Having a bottle or cup to drink the water was a cool idea too. The special glacier bus driver was fun and informative and the drive involves a steep hill so sit at the front if you want the best views. Note - the coach from the Centre takes you to a carpark to meet the Glacier bus, so if you sit at the front, I'd imagine you'd be first off and so first onto the glacier bus and have your choice of seats.We enjoyed the Skywalk. Take the audio tour offered so you can wander at will and listen to information at each point. The views are lovely, the engineering impressive and the information educational. The buses run regularly and you just catch the next one from the centre or Skywalk. I'd allow 90 mins if you do this before your Glacier trip to make sure you are back for your timed trip. The whole thing is fairly well organised with one exception. Lots of people pre-pay their visit as part of a multi-attraction ticket. However from what we saw this did not give them a timed ticket. If you do that, you therefore need to see the desk to book your timed slot when you arrive. Some people had pre-booked their timed slot, but they still had to see the desk to collect the tickets as the email etc did not have a barcode. Many people queued for the bus only to be told they did not a booking for that bus - clearly each bus has a fixed number of seats but this happened a lot so obviously this needs to be explained in a better way. Big signs as you enter the building perhaps? We really enjoyed the whole experience. It was certainly a highlight and we have great memories and photos."

"The very fact that a glacier is so close to the highway, you are automatically awestruck. In years gone by the public has been able to walk the rocky trail up onto the glacier and physically touch it with their own hands. On the occasion of my September 2014 visit, the Walkway is cordoned off to keep the public from falling into crevasses that have developed in the glacier, unfortunately we could not touch it or stand on it. Nevertheless, it is a sight to behold. There is an interpretive center with cafeteria, dining, gift shops, and tours available. From this spot you can take a bus to the walkway that goes out above the canyon, ride a huge machine onto the glacier, and some other touristy kinds of things, for a fee. Be aware that it is cold here year-round. You will need a warm jacket and slacks. Some people were wearing hats and mitts. You do not need winter boots unless it is winter.There is a driveway/pathway that leads from the highway to a parking lot where you can leave your car and then get out and walk The remainder of the journey up a craggy path to the base of the glacier. Without exaggeration it might be easily more than half a kilometer walk up. The air is very thin because you are so far above sea level at this point. It is not the easiest walk if you are not in good shape. There is no access for disabled and I think it would be very unwise to try and take a stroller on this path."

The bus was new and very comfortable. Once at ice fields there is a centralized building across s the street to park and later eat lunch. The tour bus takes you to an unloading area where you get on a monster tram to go out onto the glacier. If you tour, you may want to bring some food and drink."

"The walk up to the glacier is steep and rough, so know that before you walk up! It's very busy what with tons of people walking up the hill and onto the glacier. Just a head's up, YOU CAN'T WALK ON THE GLACIER unless you go on the tour bus. There are signs everywhere warning people to stay on the viewpoint, but people ignore them and just walk up. The signs are there for a reason people. A lake and river lie just below the surface, and the ice is weak from melting, so crevasses have opened and you have a chance of falling through! But people would go anyway, not only risking their lives, but the lives of their friends/family and those of the rescue workers. Please us caution. If you want to walk on the glacier, pay the money to do the bus tour. Otherwise the trail up is beautiful and to see the glacier from so close is simply amazing!!"

"The Icefields Center (and its associated activites) has become a big business, and can be a crowded nightmare if you do not have a gameplan in advance. If you just want to view the glacier, or walk out to it, no problem. But if you want to do any of the activities, I would strongly suggest setting them up in advance. We chose to do the small group Icewalk tour (wonderful!), rather then ride a gigantic vechicle down a long, steep road onto the ice for a few minutes, or take a crowded bus to walk out on a man-made platform (that looks like it belongs in an amusement park, not a national park!) We stayed in the hotel -3rd floor of Icefields Center- the night before our Icewalk. (A splurge for sure, but we ate p & j sandwiches!) It was delightfully quiet without the hoards of tourists, but during the day, you could hardly walk through the 1st floor with all the tour groups and people waiting in line for tickets. So save yourself a lot of time and aggravation, choose and book your activities ahead of time, if you can."

"This is definitely a ""tourist attraction"" but still worth doing. My boyfriend and I decided to do this on our recent trip to Banff. We are from California, so the idea of walking on a glacier was one we couldn't pass up. I recommend driving your own car there if you can. The Icefield Parkway is a beautiful drive and it was nice to have the freedom to stop along the way. Once you arrive at the visitor center there is a line to buy your tickets for the next available bus. We went on a busy day and waited about an hour for the next available tour. You might be able to avoid that by buying ahead of time but we didn't. Skip the cafeteria unless you are starving, it was way too busy.Once your bus is ready you take a short ride to the edge of the glacier, then transfer to the ice vehicle. Our driver/guide was fun and I actually learned quite a bit on the drive over. Walking on the glacier was really cool. In mid-July I wore shorts, a light jacket and hiking boots (tennis shoes would be fine too). Don't forget to bring a water bottle to fill up with the glacier water! This is an attraction that people of all ages can enjoy. If you live in cold weather climates this might be less than thrilling but if you are visiting the area and haven't seen or been near glaciers this is a great activity."

It is a beautiful place to visit and going on the buses on the glacier is an experience in itself. We also visited the Glacier Skywalk, which only opened in May. This gave amazing views over the Sunwapta Canyon. After this we returned to the base of the glacier for a buffet lunch that was organised by the tour company. The food was great and very well organised. After this we stopped for photo opportunities at the Weeping Wall and Peyto Lake. All in all an exceptional day."

"GENERAL: This was voted the top activity of our family (11 of us ranging from 11 to 72). This gets very crowded - we were glad we got there relatively early (11am) AND bought our tickets ahead of time. When we left at 12:30, the parking lot was full and the line for tickets was about 50 people long. THE TOUR: You board a bus at the center which takes you to the transfer point where you board the ice explorer. We saw a big-horned ram on the way. Once on the explorer it is a 15 min trip to the glacier - at one point driving on a 32 degree incline. Once on the glacier, you must stay on a plowed section, but you get nice views of the glacier, can fill your water bottles with glacier water, take pictures etc. before heading back down.TIPS:Bring along a bottle to sample the water. Take a jacket - it is much cooler on the glacier and the weather can be unpredictable (it snowed in August in 2003 by report). If you purchased your tickets online, bypass the ticket counter nearest to the parking lot and continue to the desk near the entry to the glacier adventure to get assigned a time. You need to be in line 10 mins before your tour."

"For now, this glacier is receding so there may come a time when you would have to ride a tram to stand on it. For now, you can take the ice mobiles with their $5,000 dollars each treaded wheels onto the tongue of the glacier. Be prepared to ride over and down the steep pile of moraine to get to the glacier. I've been here twice. Once after hours when the ride was closed (haunting beauty really with not a soul in sight early June) and I returned a few years later in mid July to actually walk on the glacier. It was 80 degrees out but on the glacier it was snowing. The ice is precarious so be cautious walking on it. I wore hiking boots and a poncho My 78 year companion had her walking sticks but without the ice pick tip, you have to rely on your own balance. I will never forget the way the wind blew down across the glacier. You see the blue ice which is years of compressed snow. It is one thing to see the glaciers from below and quite another to stand on one and to realize how mammoth they are and how small one feels in comparison. The visitor center is a madhouse but don't let that stop you from giving yourself this perspective if you have an adventurous bone in your body. I didn't do the skywalk as glass walkways aren't for me. I do think that the Parkway is just stunning between the Athabasca Glacier and Jasper. I gave it a ""very good"" because it is not for everybody. (Many older people on our tour walked onto the glacier and quickly turned back onto the ice mobile.) If I was younger and it was a blue sky day, I would definitely consider doing the more in depth ice walk. On the Ice explorer, to just walk briefly on the glacier, it's about $50.00 and if you've made it this far to the Icefields, why not go all the way? Not for little children."

"My friend and I grabbed the Ultimate Explorer package from Brewster which included the icefields, new skywalk attraction, lake cruise, and the gondola up Sulphur Mountain. Fortunately, for the forest and its residents, the fires were well contained by the time we were headed up and we got through no problem. We arrived quite early, around 9am and I would definitely recommend this time for independent travellers. We were shuttled to the ice explorer station within half an hour of arriving at the information centre.Despite miserable weather, our ice explorer driver was in good spirits and kept us entertained with stories while he drove us onto the glacier. It was wet and cold on the glacier (who would have guessed... ;) ) but the view was worth it. We had a quick sip of the incredibly refreshing glacier water and spent some time taking in the view. I would recommend taking some quick snaps and then putting your camera away and just enjoy the experience. At $109.95 (plus tax), we were very pleased with the ultimate explorer package and our glacier experience.Tip for travellers: the food at the information centre can be very expensive, so pack a small picnic to enjoy after your icefields visit. There are a number of wonderful places to picnic just a couple kms past the icefields in the direction of Jasper.Reminder for independent travellers: the earlier you can get to the information centre the better. We were staying in Banff and left at 6:30am (mostly due to the bushfire threat). We were very glad that we arrived early as the lines were absolutely crazy after about 1030-11 am."
