"Our tour bus arrived at the Ice Field Centre where we loaded onto a second bus. The amount of glacier melt in the past 100 years due to climate change here is mind blowing! The Ice Field is surrounded by numerous glaciers. Being driven in the Glacier Buggies onto the main ice field is a ride to remember, as the ""road surface"" is constantly changing. We were let out onto the ice fields themselves to explore within the roped off areas. Drinking free flowing glacier water that had been previously frozen for thousands of years is an amazing experience. Pictures in front of the Canadian flag that had been placed in front of the main free flowing glacier stream next to people from all over the world was awe-inspiring. Yes, this is an expensive tour! However, it is a once in a lifetime trip to a vanishing glacier. Once it's gone, it's not coming back! Well worth the cost in scenic beauty alone."
"Even as a Canadian who gets sick of snow and ice during the winter, the Glacier Adventure tour was interesting, although our driver thought he was a comedian but definitely wasn't. I didn't do the new Glacier Skywalk but my boyfriend did and I would recommend it to anyone who doesn't get vertigo like me! The Glacier Skywalk takes about an hour but I believe there are frequent departures. The Glacier Adventure took nearly 90 minutes. Definitely make sure you wear warm clothes. I couldn't believe how many people were wearing shorts and flip flops. The snocoach is warm enough, but it's cold on the glacier. (You're standing on ICE, people!) There were also other things to do at the Icefield Centre (afterwards someone asked if I'd seen the movie but I don't remember noticing one), so plan to stay at least 3 hours if you want to take advantage of everything.The facilities were mostly good, but I have to say I was dismayed by how many bathrooms were out of service. For the prices they charge, you'd think they could hire a plumber now and again.Since it's a 90-minute drive from Jasper, I'd suggest stopping on the way in or out if you are driving from Calgary, Banff, or Lake Louise."

"Touring the Columbia Ice Field is not for the faint of pocketbook. Prior to getting into line, it is worth researching your purchase options, as there are 12 for each person in your group (a family of 3 has 36 possible combinations). This resulted in a 55-60 minute wait at the ticket desk, before waiting in lines elsewhere on the voyage. The full package (Skywalk, Banff Lake Cruise, Banff sky tram, and the Icefield) is the cheapest as long as you plan to do three of the four events. Once your tickets are purchased, there is a place for lunch upstairs, which can often serve lunch or a snack inside the wait time people have before they board their buses. Once on the buses, there is no rest facilities available, so one should use the tiolet just before boarding. You take one regular bus to the drop off point where you take the Glacier coach onto the glacier. You spend approximately 10 min on the glacier before returning by the same shuttle schedule. Total round-trip time is around 90 minutes.For the faint of heart, the glacial coach (the one with the big wheels) does drive you down a 32 percent grade incline onto the glacier. There are two degrees of safety involved, as the buses are certified to not tip over unless the road reaches a 35 percent grade. The steepness of this section is eyeopening. Once out on the glacier, you stand on 770 feet of ice (when we visited 12 years ago it was over 1000 feet), and you are able to capture and witness some of the glacial melt. The water on the glacier is potable and is suitable for drinking. The last time that ice saw atmospheric contaminants was around 20,000 years ago, so it is likely more pure than anything available anywhere else. The trip is entertaining. Good guides help you learn and get something out of the trip. Note to visitors: Only an imbecile wears open-toed shoes when climbing onto a slab of ice 770 feet thick. Your feet will tread through a slush layer on top, the ice is cold (around 0 degrees), and the air temperature on the glacier is about 10 Celsius degrees below that at the visitor center..or about 20 Fahrenheit degrees. Jackets or other outwear are appropriate. Snowball fights do break out. Be ready, and enjoy. Bottom line -- a waiting line that moved glacially (while in theme) was irksome enough and caused serious overcrowding in the visitors' building to make this less than a 5-star experience. The Glacier is worth seeing, however."
"It was worth it to actually step out on a glacier and experience one up close. The drivers are all practicing stand up comics but they are extremely informative at the same time. The actual part you explore is very groomed daily so it's very slushy so flip flops are not a good idea. The tour make you pause and think about our environment."

"In contrast to most of the lush green hikes in Jasper, the hike to the bottom of the ice fields feels like walking on another planet. Creative visitors have taken the opportunity to compensate for this lack of landscape by creating hundreds of rock cairns in every possible configuration. This creates a unique photo opportunity. Take the time to build cairn of your own. The hike is easy and will take 30 minutes to an hour."

"I've lived in the mountains my whole life, and I still find these rocky peaks and huge glaciers awe-inspiring. Starting at the building, there was plenty of room for RV parking and the building was crowded but the line-ups moved quickly. Our bus to the big ice rovers broke down but we were quickly taken over to another one and hauled half way up the hill. Onto the ice buggy, it was a bit top-heavy feeling but the speed maxed out at 18km/h so it was slow and steady. Once on the ice, we were timed (approx 15 min), we got out, wandered in a small area, drank some fresh, running water, snapped a few photos, and jumped on the big-wheeled buggy to head back. Overall a great experience. I think this is a much more enjoyable, hands-on experience than walking on the Glacier Walkway. This walkway only sticks out on a hillside along the highway, that you drive beside the whole way from Jasper. There's much better viewpoints along the way than this one."

By now the Columbia icefield is more or less under total control of the Brewster money machine. But do not give up. Opposite to the icefield center is the access to the PARKING LOT right at the bottom of the glacier. In three visits I always found a parking spot interesting enough. You hike five minutes and arrive on top of the glacier moraine. There is a line that tells you not to go further (I call this the Brewster money line) but if you look careful you see to the ultra left a small bridge letting you pass the waters and get onto the field. The same access is used by the guided icefield tours which is still way better value than the Brewster bus (I am NOT affiliated with either organization but I am tired to pay too much money for no product). Enjoy the Glacier while it lasts !

"The Athabasca Glacier is a site you must see and is about one hour from Jasper. You can purchase tickets at the Centre on the Icefield parkway or online in advance. If you purchase in advance you can skip the very very long lines and go to the pre-purchase short line to board the big wheeled bus to the glacier. You can see 2% before the mountains-and the 2% is very large - the guide said the glacier has melted by 40%...so go see it now! My 16 year old was really impressed. You can get a different bus to the new Skywalk, a glass bottomed walkabout over the valley complete with audio tour on local animals and geology-very cool."
"So Columbia Ice Field experience is a definite must do while in Banff/Jasper National Parks. We stayed at Lake Louise and did a day trip driving North to Columbia IceFields. Easiest way is to book your tickets online and do remember once you go inside (and see line to purchase tickets), stay to the line on the far right as you will need to book a time prior to starting this tour. Once you get a tour time you move to the far left to line up when its your time and you will line up to board the BIG bus. This bus is very interesting as it has giant tires. You will know why this is necessary once you start the drive to the glacier. The incline and decline is ridiculously steep! Very fun. Then you drive onto the glacier (Athabasca Glacier) to experience the cold, beautiful blue color of the ice and make sure you bring an empty water bottle to fill up with melting glacial ice. Just delicious tasting ice water!"

"We visited the center and arrived just before noon. This was by plan in order to avoid crowds if there. It did not take long to board our bus for travel across the road and up the valley to the actual ice field. A comfortable and amazing ride. At the field, you disembark the main bus and board an ice field vehicle which has huge wheels and capacity to climb on to the ice fields. Part of the ride is extremely steep but we never felt uncomfortable. On the ice field the vehicle stops and you can get out and walk on the glacier. If you want to collect pure glacier water, you should take a vessel to carry water and collect it. There are usually many vehicles and many people but never over crowded. You are there for about 20 minutes or so. The pictures below are looking across the road to the ice field from the Center and looking at the glacier itself with the water flowing from melt. It was not cold but jackets are required."

If you have never walked on snow or ice, I guess taking the special tour bus might appeal (or better still a guided walk on foot) as a novelty, but we did not bother. We saw a large number of foolhardy people, including with toddlers, ignore the warning signs and walk unguided up to and on the glacier. Lives have been lost down crevasses here in the past, but stupidity abounds."

"This review is more about how to actually GET to the Explorer or Skywalk, than a review of the ice and Glacier.If driving in from the Banff (south) side, first you will encounter the Columbia Icefields Centre, which is where you MUST stop to secure your viewing time. It doesn't matter if you already have your Time booked (from an online purchase) you must still stand in line to CONFIRM that, and be told which line to stand in, for the bus to take you out the 5 minutes drive up the highway (towards Jasper.) Whilst standing in line, the ONLY ticket taker (on a SATURDAY!!!) will remind the waiting crowd that there is another ticket booth at the other end of the centre that is not as busy. Yes, it WAS as busy. What they don't tell you is that even after you have stood in line to get your Skywalk time confirmed, guess what? You still have to go over to that ticket booth in the back to get your Glacier Explorer time confirmed as well! She couldn't do both at this particular computer. This is so UNACCEPTABLE! There were NO SIGNS to tell you that, NOWHERE ONLINE did it tell you that, and what this meant was, every single party (including ours) trying to confirm a time for either the Skywalk or Explorer or both, had to have a full conversation with the ticket agent before they could comprehend that they still weren't done, where to line up etc. It took a lot of time for every single guest to get through, so allow at least 40 minutes just to get through this line even if you have your online tickets in hand. Even the 2 separate lineups for the separate buses to Skywalk or Explorer....one can't see the small signs that are on posts 4' high from the floor. When there is a lineup of people, one can't see that. Why not have LARGE Hanging signs above each line? I don't know who to blame fully - Brewsters or Parks Canada? I was ashamed of the disorganization at this world class facility in our National Parks.Imagine dragging 3 small children around as you try to figure out which Check -in desk to go to....or that one even has to go to the desk? Maybe mention that online or on the ticket, which by the way my Glacier Explorer ticket did say: "" Book/confirm a bus time unless you have a booked time"" - which we did: we had a 2:00pm booked time. No matter we were told, we still had to stand in line and re-apply as it were, to get our names on the bus load. Note: You can book a time online for the Glacier, or the Skywalk, but if you book a package you cannot book both times online. I can understand that people may not allow enough time for themselves to be able to properly book the second event properly, and so in this case it may merit the lineup to book the buses properly, but this doesn't wash if booking only one event.  The girls working at these desks were professional and courteous and I felt for them. One said that the one large sign that they did have (above her desk) had just been installed that morning-late June. Come on - whoever is managing this has dropped the ball on signage and organization. Visit the place as if you didn't know where to go or what to do (as many foreign tourists will) and see the gaping HOLES in the whole experience. We left feeling harried: from the experience, herded to the busses etc.The bus driver to and from the base to the Icefield Glacier was courteous and amusing, but talked about himself too much. I have taken this tour 30 years ago, 15 years ago and now, and the ride was taken up with chatter about how cute his name tag was and such, and very LITTLE information about the Glacier itself as given. How about letting everyone know about the rate of recession? Just in the past year...not only across the parking lot where the markers from 1883 are. What about the Depth of the ice? He said he had been there a few years and was the boss of these seasonal workers....maybe someone above him should check if he is doing his job properly because I think he missed a lot of script, he was so enamored with himself. Disappointing when we could have heard a lot of appropriate facts along with a chuckle. TIP: The Glacier: Take warm clothes for the winds, and an empty water bottle so you can fill it with pure Glacier water to drink. At the centre is a large cafeteria with items from poutine, chicken fingers, Pho, some Asian food, fresh salads and fruit. Very well run and the food was pricey as it is in the Parks, but adequate and warm food with choices was welcomed. There is also a separate dining room experience.  2 Bathroom biffies in the parking lot - Thanks Parks Canada for those!"

"A nice attraction, and reasonably priced for Jasper National Park at $25 each. You get tickets at the main Columbia Icefield Discovery Centre, and travel by shuttle bus a few kilometers north to the lookout site. It's on the south west side of the main highway, and open only to the shuttle buses. They pull in and drop passengers/pick up returnees on about a 10 min. turnaround. The attraction is informative. Free handheld audio tour units are available in all languages; they are informative and easy to use. The glass floored walkway over the Sunwapta Valley is impressive; a semicircle with about a 50 foot radius. The entire attraction is made of steel plate and beams and is very solid looking. This is a reasonably priced attraction to visit on the Icefield Parkway between Jasper and Banff."

"What can you say about the Columbia ice field? Well the large tractor like buses are one. The actual ice field is epic and vast, but this is a trip for the ordinary traveller. You are bombarded with fierce stories by the friendly guide, sink holes and climbers who disaapear never to be seen again. But this is ice field easy and there is little strenuous walking here. The hazards are coned off and walking on the ice field is as safe as it can be. However, is it worth the effort and cost? Yes, in that unless you are an experienced climber it is unlikely you will have been on a glacier. "Arrived just a few days (late September) before the Ice Field closed for the winter. Much less crowded on weekdays than weekends. Incredible experience, attentive employees, informative. The whole trip is about 1 1/2 to 2 hours, though only 20 minutes or so are actually spent on the glacier. There's a fairly lengthy line to board a bus that takes you to the base of the glacier. You then board a giant bus with 5 foot tires that actually drives you onto the glacier. The drive on this bus is fascinating. Once at the glacier, you get off the bus and can walk on the glacier. Great photo opportunities. Be sure to check the weather. We were going to go on a Saturday on our way to Jasper, but the weather was poor, with limited visibility and high wind (as well as big crowds). We returned on a Tuesday with great weather and less crowds."

"The Columbia Ice Field is amazing! Not your usual hike. There are a few ways to get on the Columbia Ice field, depending on how much time you have and what you are looking for. No matter what you decide, you will have an exciting adventure. At the foot of the mountain, right off the highway, there is a large visitors center that operates a hotel and a couple of restaurants. They also sell tickets for various kinds of tours, but most of them can be booked online. The most popular is probably the ice bus tour. They drive a group of tourists in one of those extreme bus-like vehicles with giant wheels to the glacier and let people spend 15-20 minutes on it taking pictures and enjoying the view. The other option is to book a hike. One would need to be in a decent physical condition as those hikes are multiple hour long and require the use of basic equipment like outerwear and clamps. It does get cold and windy up there even in the summer time. But it is not meant for professional climbers, almost anyone can do it."
"The Columbia ice field's centre was closed and the Ice field tour ride operator was closed as well as we were there on October 22. Which was disappointing but understandable as tourist season is over. You are still able to park and walk towards the ice fields.The ability to get great photographs of the various glaciers in the area. For any lover of nature, you have to make a trip to the Columbia ice fields."

"We spent a week exploring the scenery and geology of the Columbia Ice Fields. I found this the most beautiful area in all of Canada. Skip Banff, and spend your time here and at Maligne Canyon."
"We stopped here on the way to Jasper from Banff. As it was out of season, parking and facilities were easy to use. "I've been twice to this glacier, once in 1981 and again in 2013. The walk today is much longer, and the glacier is still retreating. I'm now going to look for my old photographs, so see how much it has changed. It costs nothing to drive to the car park, at the toe of the glacier. On the way to the car park, you'll see various little marker plaques indicating the positions of the glacier toe at different points in time. Look out for them, as it makes it more apparent, exactly where the glacier has been, and the degree to which it has retreated over time. There's a well made gravel walking track with a circular loop at the end, allowing good views of the toe. You'll be warned not to step off this path, as there are risks of falling stones, crevices hidden etc, and these will be most apparent on a sunny day, with excess melting. Pushing wheel chairs more challenging, as slope is a bit stepper than comfortable.Take some sun cream and water on a sunny day. However when we were there we needed gloves, warm hats and good windproofs as the windchill factor was very cold. Be warned the park interpretation centre below the hotel is not currently open until May 2014 and there is no signage to say when we visited, so only head up to the centre is you want one of their ice field buses or if you need a drink. The buses stop around 4pm. If you've never been close to the ice before, then walk down towards toe, or take one of the guided tours. You get a different type of experience on the bus ride onto the glacier. We didn't do this, as we've been on glaciers before in Europe and New Zealand."
Dropped in on our way to Banff and found that it was very easy to walk up to the sight seeing area to enjoy the view. If you've got time take a walk on the glacier.

"We drove through Ice Fields Parkway and were very impressed with the variety of places to stop and see. The tours stop at Ice Fields Center and Peyto Lake so expect crowds there but even there you can find near empty trails to get away from the crowds. There are waterfalls, the river and the mountains all around you. At one end is Lake Louise, a very touristy place and at the other end is Jasper, a much quieter town. "Visited en route to Banff down the Icefields Parkway. Parking is free and there are lots of signs informing you about the glaciers receding, not to stand on the 'toe' and other dangers. There are also year markings telling you how much the glacier has thawed over the last 120yrs or so. I think what is required is perhaps a ranger or two's presence to answer any questions and also to keep an eye on the idiots who cross the barriers in search of a good photo. We saw one bloke blithely cross the ropes to get pictures whilst his kids watched from the main path. Why the rules didn't apply to him I don't know but it's no wonder accidents/deaths happen. Anyway, despite this we found it interesting, informative and worrying that a glacier can recede so much in a relatively short space of time thanks to global warming. If seeing that doesn't make you switch things off when you're not using them, nothing will."

"The whole experience is very efficiently run. Along the way the driver provides some background on the history of the glacier until we arrive at the glacier where we were transferred to large all terrains vehicles that take you down this verrrrry steep incline and onto the glacier. You are taken to their preferred spot on the glacier where you have the opportunity to get out and walk on the glacier. A tip for travellers is to wear fully enclosed footwear and warm clothing as it can be quite cold and windy on the glacier. The fresh water from the glacier is drinkable. You can spend up to an hour out there depending on the weather. All in all something you would probably only experience once in your lifetime so go do it."

"The view of the Columbia Icefield and one of its outlet glaciers, Athabasca Glacier, is one of the highlights of the Icefields Parkway, highway 93N between Lake Louise and Jasper. In over thirty years of living in the Canadian Rockies, I have only done the sno-coach tour once (and enjoyed it... have reviewed it here on TripAdvisor); it's definitely a fun experience, but not the only way to see the glacier. Hiking even partway up the Wilcox Pass trail gives an awesome view from across the valley, and the Parker Ridge trail just a little further south gives a spectacular view of the Saskatchewan Glacier, another of the outlet glaciers from the icefield, and its equally spectacular valley (which is not visible from the parkway). I highly recommend both hikes! But for those who don't wish to (or can't) hike, the views from the decks at the Icefield Centre are also stunning. It's also worthwhile parking down by the ""toe"" of the glacier, and walking up the short, interpretive trail."

"If you're in this area of Canada you have to drive the Parkway. And it's not everyday you get to walk on a glacier. So it is worth stopping at the Ice Field centre and paying a visit. It was a good decision and we very much enjoyed the short hike up to the glacier walking on rocks that were crushed and moved by the glacier. It was extremely windy and somewhat cold so we put on jackets and had a great hour exploring. Have fun and hike to the glacier.

"You should never drive by the Athabasca Glacier, which is what you see from the road and is commonly referred to as the Columbia Icefields. We have a young family and so found the bus to expensive and the hike too long but let me say the 2km walk around the toe of the glacier is just phenomenal. Even more so are the signs that are laid out telling you about glacier, and about how far and how fast it is receding. For all those that think about global warming, this alone is an education and my kids, who will come to their own conclusions in time, at least are able to comprehend what it means when they hear about global warming. More shocking to me was the consistent signed about the dangers of walking on the glaciers, the amount of failed rescues and loss of childrens life. I guess I really didn't understand how dangerous glaciers could be even if you just walked on the first few meters ... yet there were plenty of people jumping the barriers and doing just that. Perhaps I will end where I should have began ... the glacier itself. It is stunningly beautiful. It is huge (though smaller than it once was) and it is melting a steady stream of an icy cold water flowing into a lake. You can see where it has deposited rocks, you can see where it has made rock as smooth as glass and you can see blue ice sparkling below some of the rock deposits. I will end where I started ... you should not drive by this wonder under any circumstance !"

"We splurged for the icefield bus, and were glad that we did. The bus takes you from the Ice Fields centre up a windy, steep road to a second location. There, you board a specially-made vehicle that takes you right to a safe, cleared spot on the glacier. You have ample time to look around and take photos. The temperature that day was about 30 celsius, but the temperature on the glacier was only about 5. We had dressed appropriately, but many tourists hadn't. You need a proper coat, long pants, and socks and shoes, at minimum. You could also comfortably add mitts and a toque. There is a constant wind on the glacier.The drivers of the ice explorer and the bus were both entertaining and informative, adding much to the experience of walking on the glacier.The glacier is not really accessible to those with mobility issues. The terrain is very uneven and slippery.Visitors can view the glacier from the bottom for free, and can also hike the glacier for free. But if you're looking for a tour of the glacier, the ice explorer is worthwhile."
"I recently organized a trip through the Rockies for 45 travellers from 5 countries. The Ice Explorer onto the Columbia Icefield was one of the highlights. But it was fun to be out on the ice, and the photos of the deep blue caves in the glaciers were beautiful. Plus, I learned a lot of about glaciers. It is definitely worth going. Unfortunately, we had to cut our visit short since it began to rain out on the glacier after we had only been out a short time. Be sure to wear a warm jacket -- it can be quite cold, even in the middle of the summer! If you choose to just visit the base of the glacier without paying to go up on the Ice Explorer, be sure to look for the markers along the walking trail that show how far the glacier has receded over the years. It is amazing how much it has shrunk but is still so massive."

"This was a most unique attraction I had the experienced in a long time!This journey on the Ice Explorer onto the Athabasca Glacier was amazing! The Columbia Icefield is the largest icefield in the Canadian Rockies. It is surrounded by 11 of the Rockies' 22 highest peaks. The Columbia Icefield is composed of 8 major glaciers and spans an area of 325sq km and is 365m thick. The ice straddles the Continental Divide, 2 provinces and 2 national parks. The snow here accumulates and turns to ice. It melts and flows to feed 6 major outlet glaciers, 3 of the largest rivers in Canada which eventually flow into 3 oceans. Remember to bring a extra sweater or jacket as it is quite cold on the glacier, even in August! Very important is to wear rubber soled shoes as glaciers can be slippery! It is open from mid-April to mid-December.Tors depart from the Icefield Centre every 15-30minutes."
"Maybe because it wasn't busy in a Friday PM, but we did have access by car to the base of the glacier, the closest parking lot to walk up the glacier base after. "We drove here from Lake Louise and it was a quick easy drive along the scenic Icefield Parkway. The Glacier is sort of a dirty tan grey color. It was very windy and quite cold even in July. You can park at the parking lot and take a short walk to the base of the glacier. Unless you take the Red Tour bus, you can't get on the glacier itself. However, the short walk to the glacier is punctuated with placards that give you the history of the glacier, including where the glacier was in 1860's, 1910, 1950's 1980, 1990, 2000, and where it is now in 2012. You can see how dramatically the glacier has retreated and how it has sped up in the recent years. Very sobering.We have just returned from Iceland and so must admit that compared to what we saw in Iceland (after a superb hike on the icy blue and white glacier), the Columbia Ice Field and the glacier there was a bit underwhelming. However, if you have never seen a glacier before, this would be a lot more exciting."

The great thing about this tour is that you get to put your feet on the glacier and have the direct physical experience. You also get to ride on a heavy duty bus with 5 feet high tires. There are only 30 such buses in the world and the Brewster company that runs this tour owns 23 of them. I don't think you can experience elsewhere in North America.People kept telling us it was only a few degree colder there but I think it was a lot colder so be prepare with layers and water proof boots. The ice was melting and you could step into a pool of icy water.

"Thoroughly enjoyed the trip to the glacier. Well-organized. We fortunately had timed our arrival well and were able to hop on a bus right after buying our tickets - no line. We were blessed with beautiful blue skies and thoroughly enjoyed our time there. They allow plenty of time to walk around on the glacier, take your picture, and let you collect the glacier water. Everyone is friendly and the drivers relay information about the area as you are being transported from one area to another. Views from the Center bldg itself are also impressive. Just one thing to note: if you are only wanting tickets to to the Icefield Explorer, then you need to seek out the desk where those are sold. The door that we walked in was trying to sell us tickets for the Banff gondola and another thing that the same company runs and we were confused at first until I said that I just wanted icefield tickets so the young man then directed me to the correct desk. It looks like they are strategically placed so people stop there first. Just keep walking and you will eventually find the right desk - it is right next to the area where you walk in to get to the bus."

"We stayed at the Glacier Inn so were able to take a late in the day bus tour up to the glacier. This was nice because all of the bus tours had left and it was not busy at all. Tickets are purchased in the Visitor centre and then you get in a line until the next bus leaves for the glacier. If you show your AMA / AAA you will get a discount which is great because it is pricey!Once on the first bus the driver gives you a little bit of information but this is only a few minutes drive to the base where you get on the snow bus. There is no getting in line again for the next bus. The bus pulls up on one side and the snow bus you are getting on is on the other waiting for you. It is a quick and easy transfer. Once on the bus the driver goes through over a few things and you are on your way. Our driver was a bundle of information and very friendly. Once in the area you are allowed off and can wander within a good sized area. Bring an empty water bottle to fill with some fresh glacier water. It really does taste ""clean"". We had about 30 minutes. I think we had a bit longer because it was later in the day and it was one of the last tours. Our driver was happy to take photos and answer questions. We were there in July on a HOT day. Once at the top though it is cold, especially if the wind is blowing hard. Jeans, a hoodie and a scarf or hat may be in order if you have sensitive ears. The trip back was again filled with information from our driver and he was happy to answer any questions anyone had. Allow about an hour and a half total, depending on the line after initial ticket purchase. My boys loved it, They had a snowball fight and had a contest to see who could hold their hand in the cold water the longest!It is a bit pricey but well worth it."

"This is one of those experiences that you do simply because you may never again have the opportunity to walk on a glacier. It's not as if you see so much more once you are up there and, honestly, ice is ice. The ride is well run, the guides are humorous and the wait times weren't too bad. The ""ice explorer buses"" leave every 15-30 minutes and there seemed to be fewer people in the afternoon than in the morning. You don't buy tickets for a particular time, you just stand in line. As for the price, one way to keep it manageable is to avoid all those places in Banff and Jasper that want to sell you a package that includes transportation to the Ice Field Center. Unless you don't have a car, there's no reason to take a bus there. Ice Field Highway is an excellent road and it's a beautiful drive.One thing that wasn't mentioned in any of the literature we saw is that the Ice Field Center itself is being renovated so all the informative information about glaciers, etc, has been removed. That was sort of a downer since we were hoping the kids could learn about glaciers. The exhibits won't return until 2014."

"Not too far from Jasper or Banff, this is an easily accessible, once in a lifetime experience. From the lodge building, a bus takes you close to the Glacier, where you switch to a rugged bus that will take you right out on to the Glacier. Both bus drivers are informative and describe the ecosystem around the glaciers, and the forces and history that have created the current environment. The ride out to the glacier is a bit of a thrill on its own, with an incredible descent to the ice. Once on the glacier, you are in a safe zone for about 20 minutes or so, with only the other bus passengers. This is your opportunity to absorb the experience and to be as close to an icefield as you are likely to get. Expensive? For a bus ride, yes. To stand on a glacier? We felt it was worth it. We were there later in the day (4:30 trip) and it was not busy at all. Try to avoid the tour buses by visiting early or late in the day. We did not reserve beforehand, but that may be wise during high season. Afterwards however, almost $10 for a coffee and hot chocolate at the lodge? Overpriced!"

"One of our family's 3 favorite drives in North America. Waterfalls at every turn, sky high mountains, and glaciers with unbelievably blue lakes. We parked at the base of Athabasca glacier and walked to the glacier in freezing rain. No admittance onto the glacier for safety reasons (think falling into an endless frozen hole and dying of hypothermia) unless traveling in the ""snocoaches"" ($$) through the Columbia Icefield Centre. I wish now we would have paid to ride the snocoaches, as it would have been worth the expense to walk on the glacier. Worth the time, up hill walk, and inclement weather that day to see."

"The trip back and forth Jasper was itself a treat. This is a real glacier and you have the opportunity to see an actual starting point of a river. Very big vehicle specially made for the purpose takes you to the glacier over very steep road. Vehicle driver are quite amusing and make the short ride full of fun. Once in the glacier you will be greeted with coldness but brace yourself and enjoy your walk in the glacier. The day I visited it was raining but I was told that in a gloomy day only one can see the superb color of the ice. It is something very unusual experience and I recommend it to everybody. Very enjoyable and well managed destination.One word of advice to save money if you are travelling from Banff to Jasper. You can stop at the ice field, complete the ice field tour in probably 2 hr. period and be on your way to Jasper. That way you save time and money for a round trip from Jasper. You can probably do it even if you are using a bus."

"We couldn't bring ourselves to spend $150 for our family to do the ice vehicle tour. The lines were long, the day was cold, windy and cloudy and the kids were cranky from being in the car. Instead, we drove across the highway, to a parking lot below the glacier. After a short, but steep hike (about 15 minutes) we were at the foot of the glacier. Our kids loved the adventure and felt very accomplished. There were several information signs along the way and markers of where the glacier had retreated from years past. On a bright and pretty day, the ice tour may well be worth it, but we enjoyed this adventure for the conditions that we had."

"My husband, my mother, my 4 year old son and myself made the drive up through the mountains to take in the wonder of the Columbia Icefields. We had spent the night in Lake Louise and then made the drive up early in the morning. When we arrived there was hardly anyone around. We purchased our tickets for our ride on the Ice Explorer. Our bus was to leave in 10 minutes time. We all quickly ran to the washroom. The rest of my party went to the gathering spot for the bus and I quickly ran to the car to grab a jacket. The bus left 5 minutes early, with the rest of my family standing right there. No big deal...we just got on the next one 15 minutes later...and they did apologize for the bus leaving without us.As it turned out we couldn't have time this trip any better. If you are driving yourself, I recommend staying in the Lake Louise area the night before and then leaving for the Icefields between 8am - 8:30am. That is the time the tour buses leave Banff so you will arrive ahead of them. We shared the Ice Explorer bus and the Glacier with 2 other couples...that was it. We had a wonderful day, clear blue skies (literally not a cloud all day), and it was 10C on the glacier, which for anyone who doesn't know, is quite warm. It was lovely to have the glacier pretty much to ourselves...no problem getting whatever photo you wanted. When we were on our way back down off the glacier we met 3 full buses on their way up. Again, we couldn't have timed it any better.We had a wonderful bus driver...he was extremely informative and funny. Thank you Masami 'Sami' Okada!!! You were a joy!I do recommend bringing a picnic lunch if you can...there is a cafeteria on site where you buy your tickets, but the prices leave something to be desired. An apple juice was almost $5. There is also a gift shop on site. If you are looking for something that states Jasper National Park and you are heading back down into Banff, buy it there as there isn't much in Banff for Jasper. But some other things are defnitely cheaper. My son wanted the Ice Explorer bus...it was $28 there. I knew I had seen it for less back in Banff, so we waited and picked it up on our way back...$24.We had a wonderful trip and it is a once in a lifetime experience. Highly recommend it for everyone of all ages. Of course the beauty and knowledge of the place is kind of lost on young ones. LOL"
"Easy to access, great staff made the trip very enjoyable. Safe and comfortable and lots of time to take in the fantastic views. However, plan your timing as the weather can be a killjoy and will block the view and diminish the experience."
"I'll probably never get to Antarctica, so the Columbia Ice Field will have to do. Approaching it on the parkway from the south, the view of this massive ice sheet spreading down from the Continental Divide is something you won't find much of in the Lower 48 of the US these days. At the top of the Divide, the ice sheet feeds rivers that flow in all directions - to the Pacific, the Arctic and the Atlantic. But the best part is the chance to ride out (in a special snow vehicle) onto the Ice Sheet and walk on it yourself. The wind, the cold, the view up the mountain are all elements of a great experience that most of us will never have anywhere else. Along the way, the guide explains how the glacier functions and how it has shrunk over the last 150 years. A visit here is a unique way to understand what is happening to earth's climate in our own lifetimes."
"Nice place to see and well worth the visit, seems to be disappearing and a pity as it is one of the great attractions in Alberta. "My son and I drove the highway 93 (Icefields Parkway) from Jasper to Lake Louise recently. This drive is truly humbling and beautiful. I would recommend the drive to anyone who wants to really experience the beauty and splendour of the Canadian Rockies. If you have an interest in physical geography, you will be absolutely bowled over by the glaciers along the Columbia Ice Field. In addition, if you want to experience the wildlife (moose, elk, mountain goats) this is the place to do it. We did the drive in the winter (November) when conditions were somewhat poor and would recommend driving carefully, but it was worth the drive. I can't wait to do the same drive in the summertime. When you arrive at Lake Louise, would recommend having lunch at the Fairmont Chateau Lake Louise as we did. That's a real treat and the icing on the cake after a lovely drive to reach the hotel. It also provided a nice break before we did the return drive. Surprisingly, the return drive was equally breathtaking as we took in the Rockies from the opposite perspective on the way back. The drive took us approximately 2.5 hours there and back to Jasper so make it a day excursion."

"When you're driving down the Ice fields Parkway, you'll see a dirty patch of ice surrounded by mountains. That's the Columbia Ice Field Adventure. That dirty patch of ice is as far as you'll get, so don't expect to actually see or touch the Columbia Ice field (except to see the edge of it from down on the glacier)You'll pay $50 (!!) per person to get on a coach, which will drive you to the edge of the glacier. You'll then board one of the ice explorer coaches which will drive you on to the Athabasca Glacier. You'll have just 20 minutes to take some photos in a small 'ice carpark'. You are not allowed to venture any further onto the glacier. It really is a small area and you'll get a handful of nice photos at best. Then you'll get back on the ice explorer and make your way back to the centre across the road.We had an extra 20 minutes on the ice, because we missed our ice explorer back. The driver told us she'd honk the horn to let us know it was time, but she didn't. As we were walking back, she started to drive away. So we were stranded until the next coach left - which in all honestly was too much time. We'd already taken some photos, we couldn't walk anywhere beyond the marked area, so all we could do was stand and wait. It's sad that the glacier and the ice field have shrunk so dramatically. It feels very touristy, it's very expensive, and I left feeling like I was contributing to the degradation of a dying ice field."
"Cool to stand on a glacier, but go early so you have a chance of pictures not cluttered by busloads of tourists. We had just one snowcoach full (30-40 people?) at 10:30, and then rushed to take pictures because we saw 3 more coaches coming all at once just behind us. Good thing, rest of pictures had pushy Japanese photographers throughout. Their big-tire coach is unique, and the driver was a good guide, but in the end your just standing on a place they plowed out, kind of like an ice-covered parking lot. If you don't have the money, it is possible to park across the street and walk to the tongue of the glacier to touch it. (I did that a decade ago for free.) Be careful, as the paid guides stress how important it is to be with .... a paid guide ... to keep you safe if you go on the glacier."

"The Visitor Centre of the Columbia icefields in approximately one hour on the way to Jasper. We drove from Calgary and decided to break the trip here, camp one night in a campsite very close to the Columbia icefields, and continue on to Jasper the day after.You can buy your ticket at the Visitor´s Centre. Tours depart very often. You first board a bus and then transfer to a huge ice explorer, a unique truck which huge tires cost 5000 dollars each.Your driver guide takes you on a very slow ride up to the middle of the Athabasca glacier, where you get about half an hour free time to walk on the glacier, drink glacier water, take pictures... Our guide was funny, knowledgable, thoughtful. He explained to us that the glacier recedes about 10 meters every year and how this is calculated; told us about the vegetation, the dangers of walking up a glacier without a guide, how to tell between glacier water that you can drink and when not to drink it, etc etc.It was an enjoyable trip. Walking on that ice that is as deep as the Eiffel tower is as tall and so much older, was intriguing and intimidating. Glacier water was ice cold of course, and very smooth. And learning about the formation and extinction of glaciers was interesting. The Columbia Icefileds, the largest of the Canadian rockies, will not be there forever. If you get a chance to visit and walk on it, don't miss it."

"We booked on one of the Ice Cubed walks on the Athabasca Glacier - you have to book early because they sell out - we were slightly confused by the information on the internet about the booking office in Jasper, which has recently moved to Patricia Street, but the phone numbers are the same.Normally the walks run in the morning, which means an early start because you have to be there by 10.00am to get fitted with crampons etc, but in the peak season they also run some afternoon walks at 1.00pm. The Icefield is about 1h 20 from Jasper and 2h 30 from Banff, so if there's an afternoon tour you can do it whilst transferring between the two and still have time to see the Athabasca Falls on the way.The group (14 plus guide) meets in the lower parking lot nearest the glacier, just opposite the icefield centre. The guide provides waterproof jackets and trousers, hiking boots if necessary (trainers/hi-tops are not really suitable), gloves and hats and instep crampons. We used our own jackets, but in retrospect we would have used theirs, as we got absolutely soaked by rain and hail and were left with a lot of very wet clothes to deal with. You definitely need sunglasses, and sunblock is also advisable.The weather is unpredictable: the day we went it was hot and sunny in Jasper and Banff, but on the glacier it ranged from sunshine to driving hailstorms (see pictures). I wore a T-shirt, cotton shirt, fleece and waterproof and felt comfortable - there is quite a lot of standing around, so you need to be warmly dressed.After some very basic instruction we set off from the car park across to the foot of the glacier, where we crossed a river by walking across a plank and put on our crampons (which are very effective - no need to worry about slipping). The guide provided a lot of information and we walked at a fairly slow speed - we were offered a hand to help us over any streams and stopped frequently. We were able to look into crevasses and millwells, and various other features were pointed out to us. When the bad weather started the guide confirmed that it was safe to proceed, but offered us the choice of an early return - the decision to continue was unanimous! We walked up to - and across - the road used by the tour buses. It was rather a shame to have the vehicle noise disturbing the natural surroundings, but when we were further away from the road they were less intrusive. Our walk lasted approximately 4 hours.Our guide was well informed and caring, ensuring that the pace of the group was dictated by the slowest members. There was also plenty of opportunity for photography - all in all it was a wonderful and unforgettable trip. Highly recommneded."
"The drive over the Columbia Ice Field is amazing !Unfortunately, it was a bit foggy when we've been so we didn't take the bus to go on the icefield but the drive over the region was amazing ! We saw a grizzly and a black bear on the side of the road."

"We arrived at the ice field uncertain whether to bother paying for the trip onto the glacier but after watching others venture upwards decided to give it a go. The trip isn't cheap at 50dollars each but the ride in the ice explorer alone was great fun. The buses take you right onto the glacier close to the snow field and the views of the glaciers are stunning. The guides were knowledgable and kept safety at the forefront of everything. I was amazed to see tourists risk their lives and those of the guides by straying off the safe area though, why don't people listen to common sense? All in all a great experience and well worth it."

"The snowbus tour onto the Columbia Icefield, is a must do....the vehicles have tires that are $5k each and they can go and DO go down 38 degree inclines. Walking on the glacier and seeing the icy blue water, the scree, mountain sheep and all the great views was well worth the wait. If you buy the ticket in advance with another attraction, you can save some money."
"We found ample parking and clean restrooms. Be prepared to go through two lines. The first one is to buy the tickets and the second one is to board the bus to the glacier. Wear a warm sweater and wind/rain protection. Near the glacier, you get off the bus and board a special vehicle to go onto the glacier. They take you up the glacier and you get to see it up close. You don't have any significant walking to do. I think this is the most interesting thing to do in the Canadian Rockies. Don't miss it!!!"
"The operators are very well set up and provide a great trip across to and then onto the Glacier. It is great to be able to get to the middle of a glacier without having to climb the ice. The guides are very knowledgable and provide some good humour on the way over. The drive on the glacier is exciting and then being able to get out and walk aroung is great. Drink the ice water, it is pure and cold."
"we teavelled with Sundog tours, a small group of 6 people and James our driver.
